description:
There are a lot of Filipinos in the SF Bay Area but it's surprisingly hard to find Filipino restaurants inside the SF city limits (you'd have to venture out to Daly City or along the Peninsula).  I passed by this restaurant on my way to the Westfield mall and decided to give it a try. 

The food and smells remind me of my childhood growing up in the Philippines.  They gave me a few samples and I decided to order their beef tapas with rice and egg.  It was a good plate of food - it really took me back to a lot of my meals in childhood that consisted of some meat with plenty of sauce to be soaked up by the white rice.  I also ordered a "halo halo", which is Filipino shaved ice dessert typically with some fruit, ice cream, ube and flan.  

This is a small family restaurant and the prices are very affordable. They also have Filipino soaps on the TV. I was smiling at the end of this meal - I guess nostalgia comes with age. I'll be coming back to order some of their other dishes.  I'd recommend this place for some quick, cheap Filipino bites.
author: Andrew S.

description:
1 hour 10minutes for take out?

When got there she said needed 50 more minutes plus the 20 took to get there. 

Would you wait this long for food?
author: Kay G.

description:
The Owner:
Manny salamat for continuing the establishment of Tess to Kusina Ni Tess. Manny such a humbled individual with awesome workers. Great conversation in tagalog although you can hear my english accent I can still have a whole conversation.

The Food:
Thank God theres filipino food in the area of downtown/tl. I have been going here for the last 2-3  years. I just learned they have a different food menu day to day. Also by going on their renewed website KusinaNiTess.com you can see what they will be serving. You have the two main breakfast dishes silogs tocilog/longsilo. Today I had the bistek na bangus (boneless) mmmm sarap & longsilog. One of my favorite dishes is laing & bopis. Theres is plenty of food and dessert to choose from here. My friends said their Kare Kare was hella good too. I am looking forward to get some Kare Kare from here.

Filipinos:
A1 Treatment & knowledgeable to help you understand what food they cooked. You wont know how it tastes til you try it. Filipino's from all over come here as well as Filipino Artists, Actors & Actresses, from the Philippines & so forth. Holla at a filipino friend so they can tell you whats really good or you can ask me. Follow hashtag or #A1LifestyleSarap
#sarapcity (Forever)
author: Ryan M.

description: What, no Kare Kare! "Only on Friday" say Manny the counter guy and half of the husband-wife duo behind Kusina Ni Tess. I stood there looking sad until he said, "No problem, try some other things". After a few spoonfuls of different treats simmering in warming pans, I went with a slightly spicy pork in coconut milk. It was amazing. Prices are reasonable and the food is home cooked like an Ate would make. Nice folks, great food and easy on the wallet pricing. Winner, winner, Philippine dinner!
author: Jeremy R.

description:
Was in town for a conference for a few days and was delighted to find a filipino joint right behind my hotel (Hilton).

My coworkers and I stopped for lunch on a Tuesday. Place had a large variety to select from, and the sweet ladies behind the counter gave out free samples.

We were specifically looking for bistek, but they didn't have it. The next best thing was a tocilog plate, which was pretty good.  They're generous with the portion and not skimpy on  the meat. They even have turon (which I came back for 2 days in a row). 

It's open early (7 am), but closes at 5 pm. I don't blame them since it's not in the best area.   Inside seating can get a little cramped.  If I find an excuse to come back, I'd order to go and eat in my room.
author: Jay Z.

description:
I've never had Filipino food before and thought I'd venture out a bit since there's so much diversity in San Francisco. After reading reviews on Yelp, this seemed like the right place to try and it was only like a 2-minute walk from the Hilton Union Square. 

When I walked in, I was greeted by Manny. Noticing it was my first time here, he kept asking me to try things. I didn't ask to try anything. He was just clearly proud of his food. He definitely has something to be proud of. There wasn't a single thing I tasted that I wouldn't order a full serving of. I ordered a decent amount of food and a bottled water and my bill was only $11, to top it all off. 

I'd highly recommend this place and I hope you get to meet Manny when you walk in. Enjoy!
author: Alex B.

description:
Great food at reasonable prices. The budget size option was really nice so we could try multiple things.
Super friendly staff!
author: Melissa C.

description:
Everybody go: Hotel, motel, holiday inn
You see, If you're walking down Ellis street better take a friend
Your boy likes Filipino food what can I say
Pancit n lumpia even Kare-Kare
Workin at KNT is Lola and Lolo no need to pout
Kusina Ni Tess is making food with love to stock the house
..........................................................................................................
If you like my reviews...give me a follow.

Super cool spot in the Ellis as other's have mentioned best to keep your eyes peeled in this neighborhood but that's any big city location right? 

Buffet, Chinese Fast food buffet-style set-up. They have a huge menu that lists all of their items for sale but be WARNED not everything is available that day.  I had my heart set on pork sisig which I love ...but it's only available on Tuesday and Friday's (sad face). 

So I went with (from fave to least fave)
Chicken Adobo - Always a safe choice and a Filipino staple. This was delish
Pork Sinigang- Also very tasty and flavorful
Beef Stew- Was the least fave and was a little too salty for my liking and I probably wouldn't get again and would replace with Pork Sisig! 

Super friendly service. They have a small , medium and large to-go options which range in price from like $7-$15 I wanna say. 

The venue itself is not that big so the start of the line is near the entrance/exit of the restaurant so it makes things kind of cramped near that area. 

Suggestion to the owners would be to list what foods are available and not available THAT DAY so people don't get their hopes up. A small touch but it leaves a positive taste in people's eyes.

All in all, a solid venue for Filipino home style cooking.
author: Rod M.

description:
Best Filipino food in this part of San Francisco
They have the soul food of Filipino food here it's cooked with care and love the beef tapas or chicken adobo but the have the SECOND best Lumpia in San Francisco that's definitely five stars man delicious food every bite will excite your taste bud an always get the garlic rice if it's not sold out bomb!!!!! I'll post pictures my next trip if I could give them six starts I would!!!!
author: Rolin S.

description: The food is always excellent, and the people are as friendly as they come.  Of course I'll be returning
author: Landon S.

description: I was really hungry on the 4th of July and happened to find this gem by accident. It was very close to the Hilton was only a couple minutes away walking distance. When you walk in you are greeted by very kind Filipino Lola's and you can see the food right before your eyes. I tried the Loginisa and Spam breakfast and it was delicious!! While I was eating I could not believe how kind the owner was offering this homeless man some food. In the city this was the cleanest bathroom I have used too!! Will be back next time I am in town.
author: Sara S.

description:
Excellent adobo chicken
Excellent sinigang
Excellent picadillo
Excellent longsilog
Excellent sinangag 
Thanks yelp grubhub
author: Charlene C.

description: I was really disappointed in this place. We won't be ordering here anymore.  My coworkers and I got hungry and ordered delivery.  To my surprised when we finally got it. I received only a quarter of the bangus... not even the bottom where it has the most meat but the upper quarter part of the bangus -____-  All of the pictures show a full fish.. I was soo tempted to call and ask for the other half. What a rip off...
author: Melanie G.

description:
Yum yum yum yum yum!!!  I crave my mom's home cooking all the time and Kusina Ni Tess totally hits the spot and satisfies my need for some authentic and delicious Filipino food.

It's not in the best location (borderline Tenderloin) and it's definitely a little hole in the wall kind of spot, but it's well worth the walk to go grab lunch takeout.  I always over order because all the food makes me so happy that I wish I could eat pounds of it.  I always order breakfast for lunch and then order pork adobo to save and eat for dinner.  Longsilog, garlic rice with an extra fried egg, and a side of lumpia.  Extra vinegar on the side please.  I'm drooling while I type this and now need to plan my next visit. 

Overall- great food, prices, and people.
author: Jessica F.

description: The food was not hot due to the door outside left open.  My stomach hurt after eating my breakfast meal along with my pork skewer.  I knew I shouldn't have gotten it because the lady ask me if I can wanted it reheated in the microwave.  2 things possibly = left over food from day(s) before or food came from the refrigerator previously cook.  Not cool either way.  Do not eat here if you want quality Filipino food.  I am not sure why it got high remarks???
author: Thomas L.

description:
When I first stepped into the restaurant, I was happily greeted by one of the ladies behind the counter. She was so nice. She asked if it was my first time coming here. Since I said yes, she started explaining some of the dishes and gave me tons of samples. Either she was really enthusiastic about what they serve, or she was hoping that I would buy a lot. Either way, I got samples. That really helped in deciding what I wanted to order. 

Most of the things I tried were really good, but I stuck to ordering their most popular items, which were the tapsilog and cornsilog. Both were flavorful but not overly salty. Having a bite of the meat with the garlic rice, and egg was mouth-watering combination. Aside from those two dishes, I got an order of the lumpia. Since they were taken out of the freezer, I'm not sure if they were made in house or not, but they were still tasty. They could use a little more meat inside them though. 

When I was done ordering, the same lady that gave me samples helped me checkout. Continuing on with the good service, she sent me off with my food while addressing me by name. How nice. That kind of service (plus the good food) would be a reason for me to want to come back to this place.
author: Lucinda H.

description:
Ive been here a few times, including yesterday where I had the LAING (pronounced lying) which tara leaves and coconut milk , Sinegang , Binaguongan and beefsteak , which were all delicious ! 
My tummy said thank you and give me more. They have a nice wide selection of food and a couple of desserts.. 
The service is great, your basic fun friendly Filipino staff .. 
They were happy to take our money and I was happy to eat their yummy cuisine ! 
In the words of The Terminator.. "I'll be back"
author: David S.

description: Had my first taste of filipino food here and i do not regret it! It's a small hole in the wall place close to union square but its extremely tasty! Has a homey feel to it and i believe its owned by a family, definitely would come back!
author: Michelle H.

description: This place straight up rocks.  Manny, the owner, is incredibly kind and welcoming.  Inside the restaurant it doesn't feel like 2018 in SF.  Can't believe I've never tried this place.  I got the stewed beef lunch special--it was incredibly tasty, filling, and cheap.  Don't be shook to try Kusina Ni Tess...it's awesome.  There's not much else to say. Try this restaurant.  Great food, great people, and a welcomed respite from the neighborhood.
author: Kevin O.

description: We ordered delivery through DoorDash and I have to say it's very disappointing. First of all the food is overpriced, for the portion that they give, it's way overpriced. I ordered Lechon kawali and it's not even crispy like it's supposed to be, not to mention the "no sauce" to go with it. I've had better Filipino food that's reasonably priced.
author: Ava M.

description:
We found this on yelp while looking for breakfast options. We were craving for home cooked food. This did not fail! 

Serving size is big with a huge scoop of garlic rice.
Bansilog and all other silogs can satisfy your Filipino food craving.

Service is very good. They were very friendly. 

We got a bit scared when we ate at night time around 6:30 - 7 pm as someone was pushing the door to get in when they already closed for further walkins. The street is not so friendly at night. You may want to visit this place while the sun is out.
author: Mae N.

description: Awesome hole in the wall Filipino cuisine.  Food is authentic Filipino food and very freshly made.  Service was 100% and they answered all our questions.  Highly recommend this place!
author: Anna K.

description: Always my go to authentic Filipino restaurant. Cheap and delicious. Very welcoming employees and everyday is different dishes to choose from.
author: Kim D.

description: Probably the most wholesome place I've been to. Manny is literally the SWEETEST and let us try everything before ordering. Everything is freshly cooked and I highly recommend everything haha. Garlic rice is tender and flavorful. The turon is crisp and chewy. The  pork adobo is literally God sent.
author: Lauren A.

description: What I like about this down home Filipino food spot is that they do not put pork in everything... So many Filipino food places put pork in the Pancit, put pork in the Mongo and often pinakbit, and they don't have enough chicken or vegetarian options. There always is something that I can eat here even though I don't eat pork and beef and get my Filipino food fix.
author: Louise K.

description: If you are looked nag for great Filipino food, this is your place.  This no frills restaurant serves AMAZING fare at a reasonable price.  They serve breakfast all day.  Their cornsilog was amazing!  I was going to take a picture, but ended up eating it all, so no pic for now.  Do not let the bare decor discourage you as it is not the prettiest, but the food is amazing and the service is great.
author: Sherry H.

description: Great place, very friendly, family owned. Loved the food would highly recommend for a quick bite in San Francisco.
author: Reid D.

description: Nestled in the heart of downtown San Francisco is a simple yet delicious place for Authentic Filipino food. Dinuguan, Menudo, Lumpia and for dessert Bibingka was all we could fit in for lunch, or we would have ordered more The owners  treated everyone like family as they entered the door. Typical Filipino hospitality
author: Lorelli R.

description: Outstanding food, quick, friendly service and extremely cost effective considering being in the San Francisco downtown area.  Here on business and you can have breakfast quickly and the food was tasty!
author: Fred P.

description: I found this place via Yelp while up in SF on business and wanted to try Filipino food. Yeah, the neighborhood could be considered sketchy, but once I walked in I was immediately greeted by the super friendly man (Manny?) behind the counter. He quickly began to establish rapport with me, asking my name, if I ever had Filipino food, and when I said no, he proudly began to pull out the plastic spoons and patiently offered me samples of his dishes (in order of the most popular). I stopped eating red meat a year ago, but I threw that out the window here. Food was delicious, and complex in flavor for being seemingly simple. The lady also working was attentive and made me feel welcome.
author: J M.

description: I discovered this restaurant by accident while walking towards Glide Memorial Church in downtown San Francisco. As I strolled passed it, a familiar smell of fried Daing Bangus beckoned me to make a 360 towards the restaurant.  It was early in the morning after all and right on time for breakfast.  I ordered Bangselog of course. Who can resist!  I wasn't disappointed with the fried Bangus.  It was served nice and crispy,  perfectly flavored with vinegar, salt, garlic and black pepper.  It complimented the garlic fried rice, fried egg and beef broth that it came with. It was a generous serving that would satisfy a big eater like me.  I will definitely return to Kusina Ni Tess for more delicious home cooked style Filipino delicacies and the awesome hospitality of the restaurant staff.
author: Sergy F.

description:
TLDR - cheap, quick, homey, hole-in-the-wall Filipino food

4 stars for the service and prices, but the food itself was at best an average 3 stars for me. 

This was my first time having Filipino food so maybe I'm just not a fan of Filipino food in general. I can't pretend I know what good Filipino food tastes like, so I can't vouch for its authenticity. It tastes very homey though, as if I were eating a home cooked meal with my parents. Filipino food seems to be all about heartiness so don't expect to find anything healthy here. Even any sort of vegetables are scarce, with food centering around meat.

Food is ordered a la carte here, cafeteria style. If you're not familiar with Filipino food, you can just point at whatever looks appealing to you behind the glass. I had no idea what anything was, so I ended up pointing and asking what everything was. The lady helping me asked if it was my first time there, and when I said yes, she was kind enough to give me small samples of her favorite dishes to try.

Prices vary depending on the type of protein/dish, averaging about $6 for small, $10 for medium and $13 for large sizes. Rice is $1.25. You can easily get a pretty filling lunch here for less than $10 with a small entree and rice.

I went with 2 small entrees and no rice:

* KARE KARE ($5.50, small)
Pork (knuckle I think?) in a peanut-based broth. The meat was a tad try, and the small size came with only 1 piece. I was expecting the broth to be thicker, but it was pretty thin and light in flavor. Served with fish paste on the side, which added a lot of saltiness, but I actually liked it without the fish paste

* CHICKEN ADOBO ($5.50, small)
Kind of reminded me of a Chinese chicken dish, but much more acidic. A little heavy on the salt. Chicken was fatty with lots of skin and a little on the dry side
author: Jessie L.

description:
While walking down Ellis, I immediately stopped because I smelled an ever so familiar smell that I was hardly expecting that morning.  I followed through the open doors, "Hi iha, what can I get for you?"

Her words were so comforting.  Feeling this welcomed made this particular breakfast just like home.  Not Dallas home, no.  It was like the home that takes you outside of these streets of Tenderloin and into a place where no hobo can get you.

I received a plate with the perfect heap of garlic fried rice, proportioned for the carb lover that I am.  Three red sticky links tagged along with sweet flowing juices after snapping into their plump casing.  

They were so round and vivid, as if I could pop them with my blunt fork.  These were not the kind I buy frozen at the Asian market; The ones that surprise me with gristle and an overwhelmingly pork funk.  These are the longanisa that make you want to slip back into a peaceful and satisfying slumber, forgetting that thing you call "work".

I love this kind of breakfast.  Sweet and savory meat with an imperfectly perfect fried egg, just like home.  

Grab a piece of suman or bibingka for an afternoon snack.  It will go great with tea, I promise.
author: Sharde A.

description:
So I was at the Hilton and wanted a quick bite, and found that Kusina Ni Tess was right across the street!!  I wanted a quick meal, so I went through Eat24, placed an order for pick-up and waited a bit.  I guess I should have looked at the photos, to better understand that it's essentially a steam plate restaurant so it wasn't necessary to do that.   Anyway - when I got there, they didn't receive the Eat24 order, talked about how they don't get the order, but that it would be on Maria's cell phone, etc etc.  Also more importantly, of the 4 things I ordered and paid for, 2 of the items were not available that day - which, again - had I looked, is totally understandable when knowing it's a steam plate / to go type of place.

Rather than go through the process of calling Maria and deal with the order, I showed them my receipt, and then I was able to substitute items to make up the same totals.   The ladies in there were super accommodating and helpful (even though I was a bit disappointed that I cldn't have 2 items I had been craving on my walk over).  Luckily I'm a glutton, and love to eat - so there were plenty of other options.  

While not filipina myself, I grew up in Asia, and had home cooking at home often.  I ended up with Chicken Adobo, the mung beans stew (mongo), a stewed pork (i think it was binagoongan) ... and taro leaves in coconut milk - all in small sizes - along in with a side of rice.  so so so yummy.  For ME, everything hit the spot and took me 'home' to my childhood.  I was pleasantly surprised at the flavours and quality.  Perhaps it was because I was hungry, perhaps because it was just that good.  Hard to tell.  

Neighbourhood is a bit sketchy - some might not feel 'comfortable' eating in the restaurant, though there is seating.  I took mine to go and ate in my room - and would likely have preferred to do that, simply because my room was more comfortable.

Anyway - worth a shot.  Definitely don't bother ordering online in advance. There will not be a long wait, as it's pretty much ready to serve - and you never know what will still be available at any given time.

Enjoy!
author: Leslie R.

description: This is the best Filipino food I've ever had ! Amazing flavors and the menu changes up every day. Kusinanitess.com . Great service and sweetest staff. The food is so filling and delicious. I love the Bicol Express pork in coconut sauce ! Always reliable for a great meal with the right price ! You have to visit this hidden Gem
author: Michael C.

description: Outstanding breakfast - lumpiasilog - fried egg, garlic fried rice , plus six lumpia (pork egg rolls)! Manila street food , excellent taste & quality. Very near to union square and across the street from the Hilton
author: Lisa B.

description: So amazing. I was here a few years ago and just came back-- both times the people were so friendly and eagerly had me taste almost everything on the menu before ordering. It was all delicious!! And cheap-- two of us overate for under $20 (they even threw in some soup for free).
author: Jared E.

description: Great place to get some Filipino food in SF. I had breakfast here with my wife and the food was very delicious and was served in a very large portion.
author: Cyrus C.

description:
This hole-in-the-wall Filipino food eatery at Tenderloin in San Francisco delivers authentic Filipino comfort food. The ambiance is very casual and reminded me of most local eateries in Manila where you just simply point out the dishes you want to the server behind the counter. The cooking style is very familiar, as if it was something that your mom, aunt or grandma cooked for you.

For as little as $25 for two people, we were able to share pork BBQ, Kare-Kare (peanut butter based oxtail stew), Sinigang na Baboy (tamarind pork soup) and Lechon Kawali (crispy pork belly) with a serving of white rice.

The staff are genuinely friendly and helpful. This place is ideal for a quick lunch. It is also a great training ground for your non Filipino spouse, especially if you intend to take them with you on your next visit to the Philippines.
author: Reggie M.

description: Just to let everyone know the business has been sold. Do not order anything on line at this time. I ordered online on their own website, paid by credit card and went to pick up. The staff which was kewl told me the business had been sold. I had to pay for a new order. I don't blame the new owners for the web problems. I found their adobo and lumpia to be good and will be returning.
author: Frank A.

description:
How many people does it take to remember the name Kusina Ni Tess? Apparently more than two -_- After failed attempts at searching Ni and Kess, we gave up and searched Filipino in order to navigate to this epitome-of-hole-in-the-walls.

The hole-in-the-wall-ness has pluses and minuses. The ambiance is simple, modest, and cafeteria-like (yes, think prepared food in metal trays over steamers. And plastic trays.), and it's more of a lunch place because they close at 8pm and run out of stuff at the end of the day: only the food on display + desserts are available. (I guess another minus is the difficult name to remember)

The trade-off is the authenticity. Well.... to be fair my knowledge of Filipino food doesn't extend far beyond the various Filipino items at my school cafeteria and fusion brunch places that include longaniza sausage. However, I trust from my extensive foodie (wannabe) adventures that I have reasonable judgment of legit good food.
 
The lady serving us was friendly and I really appreciate all her patience with our n00biness and indecisiveness. It was nice of her to offer us samples of all the entrees (reminded me of ice cream... why can't all restaurants do this).  We got the LAING (taro leaves and spinach in coconut milk) and PORK STEW with vermicelli and melon. Both were good, with a contrast between the creamy indulgent laing and the simple homemade stew. Also, you feel less guilty than my usual guilt-tripping Filipino feast of abodo and lumpia, seeing that laing consists of good honest vegetables--swimming in coconut milk, but veggies nonetheless. We got a sausage as well: pretty tasty but not mind-blowing (not super enthusiastic how they dipped it in oil before serving)

We also sampled the PANCIT and GROUND PORK--not bad but rather salty so it's one of those things that you taste good in a sample but may be too much if you got an entire entree of it.

The HALO HALO is a must-get. We've never had it before but it was a delicious mix of flavors and textures, including soft pudding-like flan, chunky ube, starchy beans, crunchy shaved ice, and chewy jelly--makes pearl milk tea seem a little too basic... Frappucinos like something from the Stone Ages. I liked how it wasn't too sweet so made a satisfying and refreshing dessert.

Total was ~$20 for 2 people, and that rivals food trucks where you most likely have to eat squatting in windy parking lots. KUSINA NI TESS. Cost-effective Asian comfort food at its finest P:
author: Edna C.

description: I mean...what more can I say about this place except DO NOT ORDER THE LONGSILOG, tocilog or skewers. Just because it's soooooo bomb I don't want them to run out
author: Anjoleen S.

description: Very friendly and kind people!!!! I wish there was a place like this in Cleveland, OH! Everything we had was amazingly delicious!!! We stuffed ourselves and left happy!
author: Ann G.

description: Very friendly staff. Food was very good. Girlfriend is Filipina and was impressed as well. We tried an array of foods: Manoksilog, pork sinigang, ?sauteed taro leaves with coconut milk, and sisig. All were good but we both loved the sinigang and taro leaves. Would recommend.
author: Daniel H.

description:
Superb smaller, locally owned Filipino restaurant right on the edge of the tenderloin district, directly behind the hilton union square hotel.

Parking? Nope. The hilton across the street has a sizable garage however, and there is a cheaper city owned garage about a block away. Can't really recommend street parking in the tenderloin. It seems safe enough, but the surrounding neighborhood is not for the unwary.

There is inside seating for a dozen or so people with the usual table/chair combos. The tables are covered with a plastic overlay over the table cloth for easy cleaning. There is a television which is dedicated to Filipino programming.

This is a smaller ma and pop place. There is a menu you can order off of, and past peak hours some items like lumpia are made when ordered, otherwise it's cafeteria style. That is to say the food is prepared and kept heated in a counter so those of you not familiar with Filipino cuisine (tip: you can never go wrong with Adobo.) can look at what you want prior to saying "I want two plates of that! No the other one! What's that called? Yeah looks good. What does it come with?" and so on. There is a soda fountain and a cooler for bottle/canned drinks (not necessarily soda). They have a filling and cheap breakfast-a rice, egg, and meat combo will be eight bucks or so. Ten if you get tea or coffee and/or a sweet. The lunch and dinner combos will be a bit more around ten of fifteen dollars for three items and a drink, a little more for non tilapia seafood. this is more of a bargain then just about any place close by.

There is no table service-you order, pay, and get your food at the counter, but the little old ladies running the place are very sweet.

It doesn't look like much from the outside, and that block is pretty much covered with urban grit, but don't be fooled. This is a wonderful family style Filipino restaurant.
author: Steven W.

description:
Went and had my lunch here before flying back to las vegas. 

Ordered cornsilog and lechon kawali. 

Typical filipino food nothing too special. Just the prices are a little pricy end up paying 19.85 for cornsilog, lechon kawali and calamansi juice.

$9.00 for cornsilog
$6.50? Idk forgot for small portion of hard lechon kawali
$2 for calamansi juice 

I don't know but the lechon kawali is kinda over priced.
author: Kirt V.

description:
If you are willing to pay almost 17.00 just for a 2 item, then go ahead. Even this Filipino food is ok,
 But the price and the portions may make you lose your appetite. It is set up where you just point to what you like, but they will price you for an A la carte. Which wasn't before. His excuse is because the rent in downtown is so high. Well you're in the wrong business if you can't strategize properly and charge your customers correctly.  Remember, almost 17.00 for a 2 item to go. Adobo, vegetables and rice. 17.00.for one person, to go. If you believe in paying this amount for this kind of set up, go ahead. Customers have been conditioned to think that this should be normal nowadays. I don't think so. SKIP THIS ONE. I will just go to the burger fastfood or pizza plaze or some Chinese fast food in downtown where portions are good and price is reasonable. Stay away from this one. Patronizing this would embolden them to continue with their pricey, small portion set up. WALK AWAY.
author: Daisy P.

description: People were friendly and the place was quite nice. Reminds me of those small cateria in the Philippines. Food was good and has the genuine taste of home
author: Erika M.

description:
Ordered the LAING (Taro leaves with coconut milk) and the DINIGUAN (pork blood stew) and it was delicious! Boyfriend got the typical LONGSILOG (marinated pork sausage with garlic friend rice and egg), a true diehard and fan-- haha, friends tried the TOCILOG (marinated pork with garlic friend rice and egg) and the PAKSIW NA TAPA (pork leg, knuckles) and the CHICKEN ADOBO (chicken cooked with soy sauce and vinegar). 

We all left super satisfied and bellies full of delicious food! -- May I add, I've been eating Filipino food all my life, and after 28 years, I think I know what "authentic" Filipino food taste like.

The staff is super friendly and once I started speaking Tagalog, she started called me "iha" which means little daughter. 

Definitely a hidden gem inside of civic center. A lot of their food is pre-cooked so you can order and be on your way! Highly recommend if you're looking for authentic Filipino food!
author: Shela D.

description: DOES NOT WORK WITH EAT24!! Knowing that, don't discount this place. I walked across from my room at the Hilton and ordered at the counter. I was bummed they didn't have the lumpia, but the lechon hit the spot and the halo halo made up for my bummed feelings on the lumpia. Do not be swayed by the outside appearance. The ladies that work the counter are so sweet and the food is good.
author: Amber R.

description:
Dining here is similar to eating at a relatives house, and that's not necessarily a good thing.  The TV was playing a Filipino soap opera, there is a crucifix on the wall, and all my peeps were there speaking Tagalog except when it was my turn to order.  I opted to get something not fried, as the pork Chicahronne (though it looked good).  I was looking for something quick to eat as I was on my way to a meeting.

I looked at their items on the counter and ordered a scoop of rice with one BBQ pork kebab at $2.99-that's a deal.  Just when I thought the woman was going to hand me the meal, to my surprise, she walked over to the microwave to heat up my food... just like at a relatives house, literally.  I assumed the food on the counter was heated from underneath.  I assumed wrong. Because my meal was nuked, the rice wasn't as soft and the meat was a little tough. I was a bit disappointed that it wasn't fresh, but for the price I paid I shouldn't expect much.

I will agree with the other reviews that the food is authentic Filipino cuisine and they offer a decent menu selection.  I do is also believe when the food is served fresh without the microwave, it probably tastes really good, as my BBQ kebab had potential.
author: Nova P.

description:
At the office we were launching our product in the Philippines and so, to commemorate the occasion, I decided to host a Filipino breakfast. (Breakfast being my favorite culinary experience when I visited Manila a few months ago!) Given that we are in San Francisco, where there's a thriving Filipino community, I figured it wouldn't be very difficult to find a good place. 

Yelp was obviously quite helpful in my search progress and soon I stumbled upon Kusina Ni Tess, which coincidentally was not too far away from our office...in the Tenderloin. Being the person who needs to try out a place first before sharing it with others, I headed there during my lunch break. The person behind the counter was Maria and as it turns out she is the owner. We got to chat and soon I realized that I wanted to do business with her: we came up with a breakfast menu that would feed 20 people!

On the day of the Filipino launch I went over to Kusina Ni Tess shortly after they opened...it was only 7:10am. However, the kitchen was already busy with lots of eggs, sweet pork sausages and rice in need of being fried up! Maria greeted me with a warm smile and shortly after I was out the door, into my taxi and off to the breakfast party...

Thanks for catering our breakfast, Maria!
author: Uli B.

description:
I found this place on accident trying to find dinner.  The restaurant itself has no bells and whistles, just some tables to eat on and a TV playing Filipino shows.  The staff was very friendly explaining what they had to offer as well as what was planned for the next day's menu.  The food was on par with what I would expect from Filipino food...just like I would have eaten at home or at a party.  The prices were affordable as well.  I ordered one main entrée of pork menudo (with white rice), a side of pork lumpia, and a side of lechon kawali.  More than enough food for one person and could have made two meals out of it if I weren't so hungry.

The only downside is that even though certain dishes are listed on the menu, it is not offered.  Not a deal breaker though.  The dishes are served cafeteria style, so what ever is there is what they have available.  

I would definitely return for the food!
author: Joe N.

description:
We saw a line outside this little hole-in-the-wall and the high yelp reviews and decided to try it. 

We had the beef stew and the coconut jackfruit as they ran out of adobo of any sort. Needless to stay we were pretty disappointed. The food was not that tasty (either quality of meat or flavors) and not that cheap (you can find much better food in this city for $20) to make up for the dirty feeling ambiance. On the plus side, everyone was very friendly and the stew was overall okay.
author: Amy D.

description: Spotted this place while walking around the conference rooms across the street at Hilton... quick cafeteria style restaurant with tasty homemade style Filipino food. Found the best chicharrones in SF so far. The ladies behind the counter were very sweet and kind too.
author: Quynh I.

description:
Authentic filipino food, hella big portions, everything made with lots of love. 

Favorites: laing, mongo beans, lechon kawali and chicken adobo.
author: Javid S.

description:
I just got off my phone and I was talking to my mother. I missed her Filipino cuisines so I went to check this place out. Sure enough I went there and had a superb grab to go meal! 

I had double size garlic rice, two red hot dogs (I never knew there's a red kind of hotdogs too), super juicy forced meat (I don't know how it's called something langoneesa?), and of course, my favorite dish after mechado, the popular pork belly! 

Though the rice was a little hard like it was refrigerated then heated up in a microwave, and I think the hotdogs were a little undercooked, I can say that this place isn't that bad!

I only spent $19 for the whole meal and I didn't even finish it and probably saving it up for dinner lol
author: Kevin S.

description:
Kusina Ni Tess is across the street from the Hilton and the next block over from Parc55. Despite a couple days of going back and forth repeatedly between the two hotels (to attend a conference) I didn't even see the restaurant. It's this tiny hole-in-the-wall that I only noticed while looking out the window at the Hilton during a break between sessions. But, my god, did I love this place so much that I had lunch here 3 times over a 4-day period. This joint is what I desperately needed after traveling and eating meals of anything but Filipino food.

First meal: Lechon kawali (with rice). They offered Mang Tomas to go with it, and which I regret not getting. I got very fatty pieces with very little meat. But they served it hot-hot which I liked. Wasn't totally impressed but I decided to return and give them another try.

Second meal: Deep fried tilapia (with rice). Now, if you don't know how to eat fish with bones, don't get this because you get the whole she-bang (eyes, tail, and all!). Setting that technicality aside, it was, again, served hot-hot and it hit the spot (especially with the soy sauce).

Third meal: Adobo and mechado (with rice). Solid adobo. Mechado not so good, but decent.

The two ladies that work the register and counter were super patient. I will be back!!!
author: Sheryl D.

description: Definitely a hole in the wall, so make sure you're okay with that (c'mon, quit being a snob!). I took some yelpers advice and ordered and dined in which resulted in what seemed like a bigger portion of food (compared to a friend of ordered to-go). I had the chicken adobo which was a healthy portion enough for two meals; spot on in terms of saltiness, tender, and fattening haha. Also had a pork and egg dish that I don't remember what it was called, but that too was good. I generally recommend getting the medium or large size and saving the leftovers for future meals, as the small serving size seemed pretty small, so you're not getting as much for your dollar. The sweetest auntie serving food here. Would come again.
author: Will H.

description: Awesome authentic Filipino food in a mom and pop restaurant. Cafeteria style ordering bit the food is fresh and tasty. You can get breakfast all day also.
author: Ric B.

description:
It was my first time here and I had dinuguan which is one of my favorite Filipino dishes. They reheated the dish in microwave; not how I would prefer for a blood dish as the oil and blood separates because of too much heat. They didn't have a combo option so I had to order and pay for each item individually as opposed to getting some discount for a combo. The dinuguan didn't taste great either.

I also had Turon for dessert but it was served cold. They don't have something to keep things warm. I was expecting it would something special in it like Langka or something. But it was just plain banana and not even very ripe one. Not something I would pay for $1.50

And worst of all, I vomitted that night. I knew it was their dish because I didn't eat anything else new other that.

It was not a good experience and I will not go here again.
author: Frances D.

description:
EAT-IN DO NOT TAKE OUT IF YOU CAN HELP IT!!!!! The reason I say this is because the portions are easily 1.5x-2x if you eat in house.

Now on to the food. The first the I came. I got small pork adobo, small dinuguan, small lechon. Total was $21. A bit pricey frankly, but the food itself is very good. The adobo and dinuguan is tender and flavorful. The Lechon is deep fried a second time to warm it up, making it very crispy and flavorful. I took it all home and I really wish I stayed at the restaurant to eat it because like I said... portions.

The second time I came back, I got a medium size of pork adobo and small lechon plus a scoop of rice. $18. I definitely could have gotten a small adobo instead because the medium was HUGE.  The ladies are very generous with the portions when you eat in and its totally worth it.

Overall, the food is very good. Prices could be a bit cheaper. I've been to much cheaper filipino joints but this is the best the city has in this area.
author: edward k.

description:
I use to come here all the time during my lunch break but for the past couple of years, I haven't had the time to go. My colleagues told me that they have really good Filipino breakfast and if you knew me well then you'd know that I can live off that even though that'll literally be the death of me if I ate it every single day! I called ahead and ordered the Tocilog which is a sweet cured pork with garlic rice and eggs. I had to order an extra egg since the meal only came with one egg. The portion for the price, which was $7+ is pretty decent. I can honestly say that they had one of the best breakfast I've ever had! Trust me when I say that's a good thing coming out of me cuz not many places I can say that are good.  

They're located across the street from Hilton Hotel (garage side) and it's a hole in the wall spot right before you go into the Tenderloin. They have a few tables inside and many times I've shared my table with strangers who are just trying to eat lunch like me. It's basically a cleaner version of a turo turo that are common in the Philippines. Turo turo means the dishes are behind the counter and you point which dish you want to put onto your plate. 

Everyone in the area especially us hoteliers frequent here. It has a homey feeling to it and they even have TFC shown on TV. Many non Filipinos come here as well and the staff always makes sure they're well informed on their menu. They'll see me a lot again cuz that breakfast is bomb!
author: Candice J.

description: We really had no complaints about this place. We went in half an hour before they closed and they still had a lot of really tasty food. Good prices and big proportions. I lived in the Philippines and the flavors of the food here were very authentic. Their halo-halo was delicious. Honestly, felt like I stepped into the Philippines. Staff was friendly. If you don't know Filipino food, this place might be a little strange but just ask and they will explain food to you. Masarap! Babalik kami.
author: Mary D.

description:
Had a hankering for Filipino food. I got the chicken adobo with rice.. I pretty much got rice with adobo sauce. They gave me a huge portion of rice with tiniest 4 pieces of chicken. If I put them all together it would not even make s whole thigh..

The flavor was good but the portion is definitely not worth the $7.50 I paid.. I could have gone to the Filipino place on 23rd & Mission Kababayan and got three times more food for the same price.. 

BE VERY CAREFUL AS WELL!! I FOUND HAIR IN MY FOOD!!! Ewwwwwww

Not a place I would go back to.. The people that worked there were also nice..
author: Ayana K.

description: Finally, as Fil-Am born and grew up in the Philippines, I know exactly how authentic Filipino food would taste like and this is the place for that. It's a tiny place in downtown San Francisco where surprisingly you would find a Filipino restaurant. It's a bit pricey which completely understandable with the cost of rent in San Francisco. This place is definitely a place to eat for Filipinos visiting SF.
author: Lance I.

description: I ordered halo halo and it came to me with neither a flan nor ice cream. I asked the waiter and he said its really like that and it has no ice cream. I thought there was some other special ingredient at first. I looked at yelp and saw the other pictures and when I asked again the person at the counter and she admitted they ran out of ice cream. Its annoying they chose to serve that at all or did not even warn the customer beforehand.
author: Ramon F.

description: I've been coming to this restaurant for years and I absolutely love their food so much, but my view on this restaurant with how they handle their food has completely changed. I ordered a halohalo and while I was enjoying it, I saw a black thing in it and when I moved it, it was a fly. That is not acceptable. It sucks because their customer service and staff is good, but unfortunately this is not.
author: Sharali T.

description: The food here is awesome . Very authentic and has great flavor and spices that make Filipino food great.  I highly recommend visiting when your in town . I drive 80 miles at least o 've a month yo eat here and take some food home too.
author: Armando F.

description: Awesome, hole-in-the wall philipino food served hot, and authentic. Dirt cheap. Friendly service. Highly recommended.
author: Chen-Tan L.

description:
Sitting in here watching. Filipino soap opera as I eat.  Very interesting.

OKay I have never had Filipino food so please don't judge this review based on that.  I just wanted.n inexpensive interesting lunch near my hotel ((Wyndham Parc55).  This got great reviews so I came on over and am glad I did.

 I'd chacterize this as a mom n pop dive.  Similar to a botequim in Brazil if you've ever been.  Walk-up restaurant with counters stools and 6 tables.  Not pristine --  a little worse for the wear.  Noisy -- fryer vent, TV, ice maker or blender, coolers and talking and street noise too.

I had half a pork roll, garlic rice and a cup of soup with pork and greens in it -- I think she said tamarind soup.  It's not on the chalkboard menu..not the English part anyway.

Styrofoam plates,  cheap pasticware, you get the idea.  

I also had a Filipino root beer in a can, bottled by coca cola and called Sarsi.  It's good -- better than American.  Tastes more like sasparilla.

If you're looking for anything other than a curious dive you might save this for when you are.  I was hoping for a bit nicer atmosphere but still I'm enjoying hanging out.

Food nothing special to me but good.  I bet Filipinos will disagree with me!
author: cc r.

description:
Tried two different dish samples the cashier offered me.  Went with the beef stew and rice, although both were appealing. Also had the lumpia with sweet and sour sauce.

 They were really friendly in here and the food was very filling. After a long day of walking, I'm worried how I will waddle home now. Spent $12 for lunch and would come back.
author: Genea S.

description: Had breakfast here- garlic rice, 3 sausages and egg for $7. Never had this type of breakfast before but was tasty. Id like to try take out dinner there. Was clean and ladies working there were nice.
author: Nala P.

description: My husband and I were looking for a place close to our hotel, and something that was relatively cheap. We got their veggie lumpia, their fried milk fish, and their pork lumpia. The fried fish was by far the best, and was absolutely delicious! Everything was fried fresh for us, and the ladies were extremely helpful. Would definitely recommend!
author: Kezia L.

description: Incomplete order and the staff that delivered the food just said my name and left. Didn't give me time to check the food.
author: Mickey L.

description:
Had Rice with Tusino, Diniguan, a bowl of Soup and a Lemonade= $14.00??
The food was FRESHLY MADE, I could always tell. I guess it was worth it!
author: Edwin J.

description: Super authentic Filipino food, quick and easy service.  The garlic rice is to die for.
author: Tom Z.

description: My first time here. I came for Pancit. They only serve it every other day. I came on a day it wasn't being served. Touran was good though.
author: Rosalind P.

description: Everything was flavorful, staff was super friendly! The only thing I didn't care for were the roasted veggies- they had too much fish sauce. Other than that, next time I'm in the Bay I'm going here again for sure!
author: Skylar G.

description: Omg love this place. Came in because I was told by two co workers and the lady that took my order had a nice smile and she was very friendly. The lumpia was awesome and I had this sausage that was sweet and it was very very good and I had white rice. I'll recommend this place any time to people.  They are open till 8'pm and you can take it to go if you want. But the lady that rings you up is nice so tell her I sent you.  Thank you for making my first impression great
author: Rodney J.

description: Kusina Ni Tess has become my SF go-to for Filipino food that tastes home-cooked. I place orders for parties, pot lucks etc as they're close to my office. Their food is reasonably priced and has the right "Lola's kitchen" taste. The owner Maria is wonderful and has become a friend in the neighborhood.
author: KJ L.

description: Halo halo is not very good.  It tastes like either the ice is bad/old/rust-tasting.  Entrees are ok, nothing like Pinoy joints in Woodside Queens.  Pretty ok if u have no where else to get rice.
author: Charles B.

description: I'm still a regular after all these years. And yes it's still all good. Maybe even better! Personal favorites: fried eggplant, bbq, corned beef, embotido, daing (veggie?). Very nice staff and service.
author: Vol T.

description:
Laing (Tarrow leaves stewed in coconut milk) was delicious. Looked like creamed spinach but tasted like thai curry. Also had delicious pork skewers. The menu shifts daily.

Quick, filling, and everyone was so nice.

I'll be back.
author: Katie A.

description:
A bit expensive, but the food is really good. My favorites are the dinuguan and the Laing. Can't go wrong with those two. 

Plus, the ladies serving are very helpful and friendly. :)
author: Rae C.

description:
I really want to experience more of the cuisine but Filipino restaurants are so scarce in the city. Then my friend brought me to Kusina Ni Tess which turned out to be a great introductory place!

Kusina Ni Tess is a hole-in-the-wall. Easily missed place with a few tables. All the food was already cooked and kept hot. Normally I'm not a big fan of steam table food, but this was perfect since I was able to study every item. The man behind the counter patiently described the different items and offered me samples. So nice of him!

Garlic Rice: It's not served during lunch. But they had some leftover from breakfast and asked if we mind. We didn't. It was a bit mushy, but still so good! 

Pork Picadillo: Ground pork with potatoes, carrots, and peas. Simple yet flavorful. It was almost stew-like with all the liquid. So good with rice! My favorite!

Pork Adobo: Big chunks of pork stewed together. I wasn't a big fan of this one since the pork had huge pieces of fat on it and wasn't very tender. 

Tortang Tolang: Fried eggplant or eggplant omelet. Basically it's a cooked eggplant, flattened then dipped in egg and fried. Definitely taste the freshness of the eggplant. Yum! 

Laing: Taro leaves cooked in coconut milk. Very fragrant. Laing usually has pork and shrimp in it, but the one here was vegetarian. Rich and heavy, but still tasty! 

I can't really comment on the authenticity or quality since I have no comparison. All I know is we were so satisfied and stuffed and even had leftovers to go. Can't wait to try more! =D
author: Marti L.

description: This place doesn't look like much from the outside but it's so good. The women cooking it up in the kitchen know what their doing and they are super nice too. Aces.
author: Micaela M.

description:
Now, I do not claim to be an expert in Filipino food, but I can say that I've had Pancit and Lumpia many, many times.  So, while walking to our hotel this weekend, we passed this little place, and I said to my hubby that we needed to remember it.

Today I went back, and it did not disappoint.  I ordered exactly what I knew; Pancit and Lumpia.  As a previous reviewer stated, this is a small place and the food has already been cooked and is kept warm for you to point at what you'd like.   It has a rotating daily menu, and you can see that menu on this website by looking at the pictures they have posted.  Service is friendly, and the patrons are....what do ya know....Filipino.  Always a good sign.  Portions are HUGE and prices are low, my food was hot, not luke warm, and although I'm not Filipino, nor have I ever been to the Philippines to visit, I will easily say this is the best food from that country that I have had thus far.  

Large portion of Pancit + 6 pork lumpia = $9.77 after tax.

Skip the chains and support the small guys.  Definitely worth a visit.
author: Britt B.

description:
So, I'm visiting from Texas and peek out my Hotel window from the Hilton Union Square. I spy, "Kusina Ni Tess, Hmmmm." a-yelping I will go. I've been wanting to find an authentic Filipino restaurant to try and this looks tailor-made.

I navigate the sidewalk denizens without issue and enter at Noon on a Tuesday. One man eating, a few more bopping through for plates to go. Overall not busy at all. The owner/partner, I am guessing, greets me with a friendly smile and surmises from my Not-so-San-Fran look that I may need assistance. She proceeds to let me try several items, all of which were tasty flavor explosions. Try that at Chez PooPoos! Yeah, I didn't think so.

I settled on a Pork w/shrimp sauce(?) stew which was awesomely awesome and Laing (Tarrow leaves stewed in coconut milk). Here is a variant that doesn't look as good as Kusina's did [ http://www.filipino-recipes-lutong-pinoy.com/laing-taro-leaves-stewed-in-coconut-milk.html ] The Liang was reminiscent of very mild turnip greens (I don't really care for turnip greens) with a Filipino coconut flair. It was really very good. I ate everything on my plate in no time.

Others have called this a Mom-n-Pop offering and I can agree with that. It definitely feels like you are sitting in a family kitchen while they cook around you. Overall, that ambiance sets the table perfectly for the food you are going to eat. I have little experience with authentic Filipino food, but I can tell you with a high degree of certainty that this is it! How? Because it tastes just like the Filipino sister of Southern comfort food cooked all day and overflowing with 5-gallon-buckets-of-love. 

I had a hard time getting over the $10 limit for Credit Card charges. Yet I am pleasantly full and the Rock concert of flavor lingers like your favorite Pink Floyd song. Awesome food that is easy on the pocketbook in downtown SF!? Whoa.

One line review: This is relaxed, honest food that you won't regret. 

If I can be motivated to get dressed early I'll go try their breakfast offerings in the morning. Considering the alternative $18 bowl of fruit you can purchase from the Hotel - I may have to upgrade that "may" to an "I will absolutely go..."
author: Clark H.

description:
Delicious! This was my first time trying Filipino cuisine, and despite some initial hesitation, I was very pleasantly surprised. 

Looking for an inexpensive lunch, we found this place near our hotel on Yelp and decided to give it a try based on the reviews. However, staring at the menu outside, we had no idea what to order. Just as we were ready to walk away, a passerby on the street stopped us and said we would love it, and recommended that we get the chicken adobo with a bowl of rice and the pork lumpia. 

With guidance like that, we couldn't turn away and boy am I glad we didn't. The chicken adobo was delicious, the pork lumpia was also quite good. The whole meal cost $14 (with 2 cans of pop!) and was more than enough food for the two of us. The atmosphere of the place is on par with your average take out joint, so don't expect much, but if you're looking for some inexpensive and delicious food, give this place a shot.
author: Jesse W.

description:
I found this place because it's close to my work and I was looking for something aside from thai or crappy pizza. The woman who was working the counter was super friendly and helpful since I've only had Filipino food a couple of times before. 

The food appeared fresh and it was absolutely delicious: perfectly seasoned and something a little different for my palette. I also appreciate how straight forward the dining experience was: order your dishes to go or to eat in and it's ready.
author: Greg Z.

description:
As I've stated in other reviews, when in SF, I run to Asian eateries because finding such in Miami can be an exercise in frustration. During a recent stay, I was excited to discover how close my hotel was to a Filipino restaurant. I used to eat Filipino food on a pretty regular basis when I lived in Chicago. Since moving south, I hadn't had any. Any. It had been much too long.

Walking in to KNT, there's not a whole lot to look at. It's a small eatery with a cafeteria-style line on one side, cooler on another, TV playing Filipino soap operas (excellent), and a few tables. This is the sort of joint where you breeze in, breeze out and chow down elsewhere. Since I was by myself, it wasn't an issue getting a table. If you have more than you, yourself and... you (?), however, I'd suggest taking the food to go. You'll be cramped. But you'll also be very satisfied.

Behind the line is your new favorite tito, Manny. He truly is the man. Fun, nice, welcoming, and mean on the grill, he'll gladly show you what's going on food-wise. Realizing that this wasn't my first time at the rodeo, we got down to the business of making me fatter. Having not had some of my favorite food in close to a year and a half, I attacked the menu: longanisa, tocino, garlic rice, pancit, and lumpia. I couldn't stop myself. Manny was pleased that not only did I know the cuisine, I came here to do some damage. It's all about respect. Since I, typically, ate my food with a cold San Miguel, I was at a bit of a loss when it came to choosing a non-alcoholic beverage to pair with my grub. Manny hooked me up. He pointed me in the direction of Sarsi. How had I not had Sarsi before? The coloring of the can reminded me of Pepsi but the taste was closer to a birch beer. It was delicious. I'm a new fan. I need more.

With this trip's meal sending me into a food coma, I knew good things were to come. If in the area for lunch, stop in, say 'what's up' to Manny and treat yourself to some affordable and delicious Filipino fare. Whether you're a n00b or a vet, I'm sure that you'll enjoy what you eat (here's a clue: make sure that pork is part of the meal).
author: Johnny T.

description: I had the pork adobo with rice. Lots of flavor packed into this dish, very good. Lady serving food was very nice and let me try samples. Reasonable prices.
author: Joe H.

description: Really good food. I've been craving Filipino food for a while and was glad I came here. It is kalenderia style with some short order. I was really pleased with selection of foods. I got sinigang pork and was transported back to the Philippines. It wasn't too sour. I also ordered the Laing was happy with that. My wife got chicken adobo which was tasty as well. Got turon or fried banana. Was pleased with it especially since they added jackfruit in it. Would come back again.
author: Max W.

description: It's a hole in the wall and I usually do take out. My favorite Filipino food in SF. Keep in mind I said SF, everyone always says, Daily City but I'm not in Daily City, I'm in SF. There is a daily menu and I try and go when they're serving afritada. The turon and halo-halo so good and great portions compared to other Filipino restaurants. I grew up in a town that has a military base nearby and this white girl was introduced to every Filipino dish and yes I do eat dinugaun and they have it here. SF is lacking with Filipino food and I'm so happy I can stop bugging my Aunties to make me food.
author: Sarah T.

description: Most the food is good got the Longansilog and Tosilog egg was cooked well.  The Garlic fried rice like others have said tasted stale.  Way to hard and dry.  Should have just gotten steam rice instead with the silogs.  Also got my delivery order wrong gave me pork adobo instead of what I ordered chicken adobo.  Would eat here again with a few adjustments on what to order.
author: Jay H.

description: Great filipino cuisine. Simple and delicious! I come and pick up breakfast or lunch here often. Friendly staff
author: Maryanne H.

description:
Stayed at a hotel nearby for a conference. Ended up eating here three times. Twice for breakfast. 

The food is very authentic buffet style. For dinner I have had the menudo and the bistek. I came in too late and they were out of chicken adobo.

For breakfast I have had the tosino and the longanisa combos. They gave me a sample of the adobo squid and I wish I weren't heading home tonight or I would be back for that. It tasted delicious.
author: gabriel o.

description:
I was dragged in here many moons ago ...the neighborhood made me feel mildly unsafe...but also told me that I was probably going to eat something good.  And oh yeah..the garlic rice and laing hit the spot and i was a convert!  Having eaten many things on the menu, I have to say the laing (taro leaves cooked on coconut milk) and adobo are my favorite.  The adobo is just a perfect amalgamation of soy sauce, ginger, hint of garlic and the coconut milk just tempers all the spice and works fabulously with the sticky rice served with it.  Add the vegetal and delicious quality of laing and its a fabulous lunch!

Oh a word of caution : don't try to go there too much later than 3:30 or so,  I have found them running out of food and if you want the full experience, get there for lunch, preferably with 6-7 people and order a bunch of stuff and eat it all!!!
author: Sunay P.

description:
Glad to know a classic style Filipino restaurant exists downtown. Authentically prepared without the fusion hippy crap. Good Filipino soul food. 

Sinagang pork was tasty but could be more sour but I like everything extra sour. Probably suits most people's palate. Nice, simple, comforting food.  Decent portion and reasonably priced. I really appreciate they left the soft bones in, just like mama prepares it.
author: Glenn A.

description:
I've been to Kusina only about three times because I'm almost never in that neighborhood lunchtime.  But it is a wonderful place.  It's inexpensive, crowded, and crudely furnished, but a place for a wonderful lunch experience.  It has two properties I value in an inexpensive restaurant, and which are necessary to make such a place a winner:  Each dish is just a little bit more interesting/exciting than the generic standard for that ethnic dish; and the owner/manager/employees really really care that you ENJOY your meal.  They take the time to explain dishes at the counter, and to give samples.  And they are genuinely nice people!

A few years ago while attending a tech conference in the hotel across the street, my CEO asked for recommendation were to take a couple other high-tech executives.  I explained the nature of the place (styrofoam, linoleum, plastic, just a crowded hole in the wall) but that the food was exciting.  Later I saw them all there, and they were thrilled with the meal.  These were bigwigs with expense accounts who could have gone to a $$$ place rather than a $ place, but they were happy.

That the owner really CARES that you enjoy your meal is the most important quality of a fine restaurant.  Everything else taught at Cordon bleu or CIA is just technique.
author: Steven H.

description:
The fam wanted Filipino food, so I yelped the closet thing to Union Square and found this. The area is a little sketch, street parking only, and place is pretty hole-in-the-wall-ish. My dad is a hard man to please, but holy shit, after we started eating, he was content.

The food here is pretty legit to homecooking. Good turon, laing (sp?) and by request, they will make fried adobo. Yes, I said it, FRIED adobo.

Boo on them being out of sinigang when we went on a cold and rainy Saturday. And their lumpia isn't handmade. Also, cash only. But it's definitely still worth a visit for some legit food.
author: Kris I.

description: I returned to Kusina ni Tess last week while I was in town for a conference. Love the food, love the people who cook it! Kusina ni Tess is in an iffy part of town. Sometimes homeless people walk in to beg and the cooks give them a large helping of rice and one of the dishes. So this place is definitely for people who don't care about that. Their food is fresher than food at the Inay restaurant at the Metreon.
author: Nat V.

description:
So, here's the thing: Kusina Ni Tess is, technically, open unitl 6:30.  Most of the time.  Maybe.  

But if you come there at 5:15, the only food available will be a handful of leftover items from lunch, in steam trays.  And no, they won't make anything for you off the menu.  Do NOT attempt to go here for dinner.

I suppose they stay open until 6:30 to sell lumpia; it's certainly not to serve other food.  The place is probably better for lunch.
author: Josh B.

description: Place is not in the best or near best area...  I'd say barely decent area.  Never got to taste the food because we Arrived at 7:45am to find the doors locked and the cook inside just ignored us.  Ohh yeah the place is supposed to be open at 7am.  I couldn't be bothered to go back.
author: G M.

description:
For $5, you can get a heaping pile of rice with a little tublet of adobo, which comes in chicken, beef, or pork forms. Pork adobo was pretty good with the fatty chunks of pork just melting into the vinegary sauce. Great with a hit of more vinegar even. Beef stew comes with carrots and potatoes, which would have been nice for some contrast. 

We snagged a fried banana and jackfruit roll for a buck something before leaving. Even cold, the sugar crackled coating was tasty.

Menu doesn't have explanations of what things are, but the ladies behind the counter were super friendly about us hemming and hawing about what to get.
author: Kevin L.

description: Absolutely delicious. The sweet manager let us try just about everything before we made a decision (try the blood stew, it's pretty good!) . I ended up with the pork stew, I felt like the adobo was too salty for my taste. I got it with the garlic rice which was perfectly sticky and aromatic but not too strong. Overall, super tasty, inexpensive, and totally worth the wait
author: Katherine M.

description: Seems like Kusina ni Tess has gotten better over the years since I first tried them. They've gone through a couple of updates/renovations (as far as I've noticed). Their space is bigger now, still a small place, but they have more tables and chairs where people can sit. Their food selection also seems to have expanded. I probably go there once every few months and they always have a good variety: laing, adobo, sinigang, corned beef, fried fish, turon, bibingka, kare kare and some others are usually on rotation. Their pork sinigang is so good! Not greasy, well-flavored and has balanced portions of meat and veggies. They now accept credit cards too but I usually pay with cash.
author: HM N.

description: Seriously all their dishes are tasty. I wish there were more filipino places where I live in the eastcoast. I didn't give it five stars because I have had tastier, but if this is all you know of filipino food, it is pretty amazing. Also, the stars don't represent the ambience, it is def not a place to bring anyone  if you are trying to impress them, but otherwise it's fairly clean, but not spotless. Nonetheless the food is just plain good! A plus is they have breakfast silog! Yummm!
author: Elyse C.

description: This is one of the better Filipino restaurants in SF. I came here for lunch with my hapa Filipino friend. The food was good. I like how they have bbq sticks, but they only had a few left. The halo halo dessert didn't taste as good as the one I had at another restaurant. Pretty good overall.
author: Jennifer T.

description: In San Francisco for a meeting.  Was craving for some Filipino food.  It's a small lil family owned place.  Ordered sinigang and embutido for dinner.  Sinigang was actually very good and full of flavor.  Not bad for $13 with a coconut drink.  Ordered fish and pansit to go for the kids.  Will definitely come back for more when I'm in the area again.
author: Lorie N.

description:
Kusina Ni Tess - "Tess' Kitchen" - has a prime location near Union Square.  The place ain't posh by any stretch, it has the size of a broom closet and the feel of a chaotic market, the epitome of hole-in-the-wall restaurant.  Nevertheless, you'll find decent lunch options here.  In a nutshell, this place serves good cafeteria-style filipino fare served by a nice and friendly elderly lady who seems to take pride in her work.  Portions are generous and the menu changes daily.  Plus the flavors are fantastic, without the greasy feeling.

Fair warning though, do not take clients here, or anyone you're trying to impress.  But if you're looking for a relatively cheap Filipino food in downtown, it turns out that your only bet is the best bet.  Good flavors, good food.  I'll be back.
author: Angel S.

description: For some reason everytime I try a filipino restaurant I get disappointed all the time because the food quality is always not that good, this place is pretty much like a carinderia on which I don't mind but food serving is small, ordered lumpia and it was soggy inside. Ordered bangsilog which is combination of Boneless Fried Milkfish, Garlic rice and Egg And i was so disappointed that my rice and fish was COLD, lucky they run out of fried eggs so i got a fresh fried egg! lol everything was on a warmer so u expect food is hot but NOPE!!!! IT WAS COLD! opsss got carried away there since I like to have my food STEAMING HOT! my bf's first time to eat at a Filipino resto but he likes longanisa but he saw the lady put the longanisa on a deep fryer! Now thats weird lol. pasensya na po!
author: Stephanie D.

description: Loved it. I was so excited to find filipino food down the street from where I was staying at Park 55. It was small and homey with TFC on the TV just like home! Very nice people, they gave my non-filipino companion tasters which was nice. They knew that I knew what was up. Haha. It was definitely comforting.
author: G. F.

description:
This was my first trip to San Francisco and my first visit to a Filipino restaurant, and I very much enjoyed both.  I arrived about thirty minutes before closing to dine in and was not feeling in any way rushed.  Although I have enjoyed some success cooking a few Filipino dishes at home and have read up some on the cuisine, I still was unfamiliar with many of the courses being served.  The woman working the counter was very patient and explained to me what each of the dishes were and offered the opportunity to try the dishes before ordering - not many places that I have been to allow you to do that.  It was as if I was a guest at the family table.  I passed on that offer all the same and ordered small portions of the bistek, chicken adobo, and an eggplant omelette.  It was all quite flavorful and a nice dinner and experience on my last night in the Bay Area.

The venue is not fancy and the cuisine is not decorated with any sort of intricate garnish or served on expensive place settings.  If you're a tourist seeking that kind of experience, do your homework and go somewhere else.  For an experience that is more along the lines of filling your plate with good honest Filipino home cooking in a reasonable yet modest setting, I believe that this probably hits pretty close to the mark.  I plan to return on my next stay in SF.  Enjoy!
author: Chris C.

description:
A small restaurant selling very authentic Filipino food.  Customers are mostly Filipino, plus perhaps a few adventurous types.  I was part of a group of adventurous eaters, much to my benefit.

I was here a few months ago, so I can't remember all of what I ate, but the bopis (minced pork heart and carrots in a spicy sauce) is great.  The desserts were good, too.

This is a tiny place.  If it's busy then there may not be a place to sit.  The decor is minimal, and you'll be eating with plastic utensils on paper plates if that kind of thing matters to you.
author: Tim B.

description: This place has been open probably since I was in middle school, maybe even longer than that. I must say, it has changed over the years. I recall there didn't used to be a lot of seating, and it used to look more run-down. Now, they've changed the paint job and offer plenty of more seating. That's always a plus. They also have a big menu board now, and I noticed they've added way more options, including a silog section. Apparently they've changed ownership, which probably accounts for the changes I've seen. The staff now are a lot friendlier than before, which I appreciate. The only negative things I have to say are that the prices of the food went up, and therefore, I don't believe it's worth paying for. I also have to add that the quality of the food isn't that great. My issues were that some of the food seemed undercooked, or lacked flavor overall. I just want a Filipino restaurant in the Tenderloin that offers really scrumptious food, that's all :(
author: Rachel M.

description: I want to give more stars but I can't. The food is ok but the lady serving was the sweetest Auntie! You kinda feel like you're at a relatives house where there's files and a fax machine behind you! Super kind hospitality though, I think if you're in the area you could Prob grab something here.
author: Marie P.

description:
Geez, who knew finding a good place for lunch in San Francisco would be so difficult? I figured the city would be littered with good eats, but I'm beginning to think they're located everywhere except within walking distance of my workplace in Union Square. Sorry, but spending double-digits for lunch in a mall food court is unacceptable, even if people hail the San Francisco Shopping Centre as the best mall food court ever. (Note to self: Before accepting a job offer, consider salary, benefits, and local dining options. I'm kidding... Maybe.) 

Kusina Ni Tess, I should've known you would be the answer to my stomach's prayers! I walk by this tiny restaurant on my way to work and the delicious smell of homemade Filipino cuisine wafts through the cold morning air. I turn my head and do a double-take every time as if to check out a hot Filipino guy, but better - hot Filipino fooooood!

I finally had a chance to try Kusina Ni Tess. The food is served a la carte and for a mere $7, I got a white rice and my choice of two sides. The woman there was very nice and offered samples of Filipino dishes I haven't tried before. I went for the chicken adobo and laing (taro root leaves, shrimp, pork, and coconut milk) and both really hit the spot. Portions are large enough to feed two people or a light dinner for yourself latter. Gotta love that!

Four stars for this hole-in-the-wall jewel that won't put a dent in your wallet and feeds you a ton of food just like a typical Filipino mom!

(P.S. Kusina Ni Tess is sandwiched between an adult bookstore/videostore and a liquor store. A perfect storm? I'll let you decide!)
author: Sylvia D.

description:
I was in SF for a couple of days of training and decided to check out this restaurant since it was close to where I was. Plus I really enjoy Filipino food. 

It's a very small location. There are just a handful of places to sit and it's very narrow. I got the sense that most people ordered their food to go. I on the other hand ate there and because it was so small had to share a table with another customer.

While it's probably not the freshest Filipino food being sold I couldn't complain because their price was so cheap. They have their food on burners and sitting out kind of like if you were to go to Panda Express. For the price you can't complain. For just a little over $5.00 I was able to order a plate of rice, chicken adobo and a side of soup.

Servers were friendly. Not very talkative but they were also somewhat busy. I would definitely go back but I just wish they had more space.
author: Yong Jae C.

description:
Went here a couple of months ago when I was visiting SF. It has that hole in the wall feel. Everything is ordered over a buffet style setting, scooped onto a sad paper plate with some plastic utensils on a plastic tray. So why the 4 star review? You can't deny the food here is GOOD. Plus I hate to admit it, but the atmosphere of this place is on par with most Filipino restaurants I've been to (at least on the East Coast).

Came here for breakfast so of course I had to go for the fried garlic rice. Along with that, got the longanissa and corned beef. I think two eggs were supposed to come with each plate but they didn't have enough for both me and my boyfriend, so we got to pick a different side.

I also got the buko pie (coconut pie), which was a bit too much for us after our hearty meal. But still very yummy.

Definitely a place you'd want to just grab your food and go. Staff is extremely friendly and all the food was SUPER cheap.

Please come to New York.
author: Noelle B.

description:
I'm not too familiar with Filipino food so I never know what to order when I come here, but the staff are super friendly and will let you try anything beforehand and everything I've gotten so far has been delicious!

Big portions, lots of variety, super fast, super friendly, very affordable. I love the mom-and-pop feel. Only downside is the food doesn't seem overly healthy and is a bit fatty.
author: Anthony P.

description:
My friend and I walked in for Saturday lunch and immediately were offered free-heaping-spoonful-samples of all the delicious food waiting, no -- yearning to be eaten. The server might have thought we were tourists, but I'm totally okay with that if it means more free-heaping-spoonful-samples. We couldn't decide what to have since everything was so unreasonably delicious, but that was no matter; the kind server said he would give us two of our choices and then we should come back another day to round out our desires.
