I don't remember the names of the delicious food, but there was one slightly spicy coconut milk and leafy vegetable curry like dish and some scandalously hearty beef stew. Both of these were delicious on top of some garlic rice, and the whole deal was sealed by a cream cheese filled rice cake.

Go for the food, and bask in the kindness of the staff. They really are so wholesome and nice. How nice? The server made sure we knew that if we chose the cheddar rice cake, it was just a few hours older than the cream cheese rice cake, as he only wanted the best.
author: David S.

description:
My previous experiences with Filipino food were brief so I was glad to find this place so close to my office.  Though I'm not normally into steam tables/buffets, it was nice in this case to be able to see all the food.  The staff are super friendly and will describe and let you taste all the dishes before you have to make a decision.  Great vibe and experience for a novice to Filipino food.

The place is divey.  It's very small and cramped and a bit sweaty.  The prices are decent.  Not super cheap but what I would consider good value.  

And the food is pretty good too.  It is a bit oily, like most fast food, but it's fine to eat every once in a while.  And it sure doesn't take away from how good it tastes.  Out of all the dishes I tasted I ended up going with the pork soup, and I wasn't disappointed.  I think one dish is enough for lunch.  You can get two dishes if you're hungry.
author: Jean K.

description: First...GREAT SERVICE!  We were able to taste everything that was available. The cook was very friendly and wanted up to try it all. The blood pork was phenomenal. Don't let the word blood deter you. Try it and you will love it. Tastes like great pork roast. It's also gives you a real big city/mom and pop experience.
author: Kyle T.

description: One of the worst Filipino restaurants ever!!!!!!! Very unhygienic and disgusting food.
author: Leslie M.

description: Authentic Filipino food. I'm all for local food, local authentic food. My friends and I ate breakfast here, and we were literally blown away & the food filled us up until the afternoon time. They give you large portions with a decent price ($5-7), I ordered the rice, egg, and the tiny sausage-like meat ($5.50). I wish I would have eaten there for lunch/dinner!
author: Angie T.

description: Went here since it's the only filipino resto in the city, was craving for kare-kare but was only available on fridays but the pork paksiw & chicken afritada were good...it's a 'carenderia' or hole in the wall type of place which is alright since I miss that kind of ambience just like back in pinas. overall, it's good.
author: Lizzy D.

description:
So i have been looking for a great filipino restaurant in SF, well i found it. While yes i am a gringo i have traveled to the Philippines a few times and this place is the real deal. 10 bucks gets you a huge portion of pork adobo ( amazing ) with rice and lumpia.
Found my new dig!!  ( Cash Only )
author: natasha g.

description:
Michelle Obama should launch her crusade against obesity here!  Enormously huge portions, fat intensive mains and enough white rice to feed a bayan.  What a worthwhile indulgence!!!  I find that I can squeeze 3-4 work lunches from only 2 of the 2-item combination plates.

Pork Adobo: Tender pieces of well marinated pork belly with the melt in your mouth fat still attached.  You should encourage your server to pour extra of that not-too-vinegary adobo sauce on the rice since such a combination is amazing.  Would have been nice if a few pieces were fried for texture contrast, but still great as is.

Pancit: They used the rice vermicelli noodles as opposed to the canton egg noodles.  Packed with flavor.  Great job on making the vegetables (carrots, onions, string beans) a firm, yet not raw texture, and daintily sliced.

Caldereta: Very tender despite being a stew quality cut of beef.  The carrots are just there.  The potatoes seem a bit undercooked.  I used the onion vinegar sauce to add a little personality to this humble dish.

Giniling na Baboy: Reminds me of Indian/Pakistani keema with the peas and diced veggies (carrots, potatoes, green peppers).  Mixes perfectly with the rice as it can disburse evenly on top of the individual grains.

Banana Spring Roll: We've pretty much had this at any Asian restaurant which strives to offer a dessert besides orange slices.  The spin here is a crunchy sugar coating layer on top of the already fried roll skin.  It works, it's tasty.  The banana inside could stand to be a tad fresher though.
author: Adam B.

description:
alright! my first filipino food.

we didn't have a clue, and it showed. the lady at the counter was super helpful describing what they had that day. 

we decided on:

kare-kare
chicken adobo
a sour-ish soup that i don't remember the name of

super. delish.

it was $9 and some change for food + drink for one. my filipino colleagues tell me the price is a little high for the quality and surroundings, but hey. SF, right?

i don't live or work in the neighborhood so i don't see myself going back often, but still nice to check another cuisine off the list.
author: Shawn C.

description:
Pork BBQ, Turon, Chicharrone all very good.
This place is solid! Super Sarap!
Sarap talaga ag mga binibenta nila dito.
author: Geordie E.

description: Yelp hours indicated that this establishment opens at 7 am.. Hours posted by the door indicates the same thing. Got there at 9 as we have a flight to catch, and they were still closed! Door was partly open and when asked, the "masungit" or snooty worker replied "yes, still closed" without batting an eyelash. Next time, please adhere to the hours you guys post anywhere. I guess, what can you expect it IS a Filipino establishment.
author: Kristine T.

description:
I love this place! I had to go to the Philippine Consulate yesterday, and since I was starving after, I was pleased to find out that this Filipino restaurant was just a few minutes away from it.

It's definitely a Mom & Pop kind of restaurant. Small space, but owners were willing to ask people if they'd be willing to share tables with others, which was very nice of them! I ordered Kare-Kare, and I realized how much I missed it! They definitely cooked an authentic Kare-Kare. I also ordered Turon (fried Plaintain) and that was a great move! I only spent $7.20 including taxes, and with that amount of money, I already had a full meal and a dessert. Definitely worth it!

I'm coming back for sure! In fact, I'm already thinking of coming back today if I'm not too lazy to make the 20-minute walk to the restaurant from my work :)
author: Rochelle B.

description:
Kusina Ni Tess, my first taste of Filipino food in nearly 20 years, damn near knocked me on my ass. Want the short review? Delicious, flavorful, welcoming, and affordable.

When going somewhere new, I always ask an employee what they would recommend. I figure if I don't like something a restaurant is enthusiastic about, I'm probably not going to like the rest of their menu.

When I asked this question at Kusina Ni Tess, the gentleman's eyes lit up. You could tell he loved making recommendations. He responded by asking if it was my first time with Filipino food, and after confirming so, said he wanted me to try a couple of things. With around a dozen or so items in their food display, I expected he would have me try one of two of his favorites.

"Do you like noodles? Try these rice noodles!" He says while handing me a plastic forkful full of a stir-fried rice noodle, jammed with vegetable goodies.

Before I even have a chance to swallow, a new fork appears in front of me. "Here, try this beef steak." He gives me a decent sized piece of crazy tender beef steak that was dripping with what I can only assume was liquefied happiness.

"You must try this pork. I think you will enjoy it." Another fork enters the arena, this time with a piece of pork cooked in soy sauce and I'm really not sure what else. "Damn, should I get that instead of the beef steak?" I ask myself.

"I want you to try this." Yet again, another fork, this time with a large piece of dark meat. Without asking what it is, I eat it up. He said it was a pork blood stew. At this point, I can't tell if he's really just this enthusiastic about his food or thinking it would be funny to fill me up.

"I don't want you to make your decision before trying this. Do you like corned-beef hash? This is the Filipino version. I enjoy corned-beef hash, and it was obvious this was a version of it. The biggest differences I noticed were the larger than normal potatoes and the higher than normal amount of... I'm not sure what it was. Grease? Oil? Juice? I really have no idea. It was superb.

 "Have you ever had taro leaves?" Until that time, my only experience with taro had been taro boba smoothies. I tell him this and that I enjoyed it, but essentially that was a no. At this point, he hands me a fork with a bite of a leafy, creamy, mess. Taro leaves cooked in coconut milk. As I learned from the taro smooth, it's a hard flavor to try to describe. With a texture best compared to creamed spinach, there was most definitely though two very distinct flavors to this dish, both the taro and the coconut, with neither overpowering the other too much.

 "You didn't get to try this one yet". One more fork, one more hunk of meat. This time, it was another piece of pork, pulled from some stew. It was both sweet and sour, and from what I could tell there were different pieces of fruit mixed into the stock.

I began to order, and started off with the rice noodles. Before I could even choose my next item the wonderfully gracious man says something to another employee and then exclaims. "The pork chops are done now. Please try this one more thing." He turns around, grabs a pork chop and cuts off a piece to hand to me with a pair of tons. Hey, look mom, no fork needed! It was one of, if not, these most tender and flavorful pork chop that I've ever had.

At this point, I imagine my mind was running wild with options. With a gun to my head, I chose the beef steak to go with my rice noodles. Yup, I ordered the very first two items I tried. Additionally, I ordered some white rice and a bbq chicken kabob. The kabob had been staring me down since I arrived, so that was a must. The beef steak was served in a decent sized plastic container with lots of meat, and a good bit of sauce. I seemed to eat the meat out of the container while pouring the outrageous sauce over my rice. Along with all of this they also gave me a cup of beef broth that I sipped throughout the meal. Meat as a drink? OK! All of this food? Just over $11. "Git outta town, James!" I will not, because that's what it cost. An absolute steal.

Heads up, it's cash only. With only 4 or 5 tables (all full when I first entered) you should also be prepared to get your food to go. Still, absolutely worth those minor inconveniences. They obviously love what they are doing and are, with good reason, proud of their food. If you are anywhere in the vicinity of this place, it's a must try.
author: James D.

description:
Definitely not a place you would expect to find some good food. I had some of their bbq sticks and they were good. Service was fast. 

parking sucks as its on the street and if there is no spot, parking garages are next door.
author: Roger A.

description:
Very hole in the wall place, the menu was a bit confusing and the food was okay. It was all really oily pork stuff.

Given the location and setting, I thought that it would be cheaper, which it wasn't when you added on the extra cost of rice and all.
author: Adelyn Z.

description: Wonderful little restaurant. I came in not knowing anything about Filipino food, and it was probably pretty clear to the woman behind the counter: she offered samples of three different dishes, and I ended up getting a combo plate of two (the pork adobo and one other whose name escapes me). Great food, friendly people, highly recommended.
author: Darius K.

description: A little gem for Filipino food. A favorite dish was the beef stew over rice, very flavorful and hearty, try at least once.
author: N A.

description: First time trying Filipino food here! Stumbled upon this place cause I was wandering around Powell st. Yelped the area for some cheap eats and I came across kusina ni Tess. I shared a platter of rice with beef and pork stew. We also got Lumpia and coconut young pie which was delicious! There were chunks of coconut in the pie and the lumpia was crispy. It's best with sweet and sour sauce. They also have banana ketchup. The pork stew was very flavorful while the beef was tender. All in all it was a great meal. The atmosphere may fell like its a hole in the wall but it was cozy and it made the food feel more authentic like home cooking. Great food for a great price.
author: Virginia Y.

description:
It's a little hole in the wall place that you'd never find, unless you knew where it was or someone told you about it.  It's a pretty small place with about 4-5 tables.  You need to move if someone needs to squeeze into the back area.

The food was good.  It's Filipino food.  And it's pretty cheap.
Oh yeah, and they give you A LOT of rice.  But hey, it's Filipino food.   No amount of Filipino food can be had without rice.  But man... that was A LOT of rice!!!  The BBQ skewers were very tasty!!  Just like mom makes.

If you want cheap Filipino food and don't give a rats a** about ambiance (that is, if cheap Costco tables and TFC blaring on the TV), then go for it!
author: Marc E.

description:
Was craving Filipino for awhile due to being exposed to it a few weeks prior to coming to Kusina. And when I Yelped for Filipino cuisine places nearby, this place was like the only option.I don't know if it was my initial experience of Filipino food that was utterly too good or every place makes the food differently or what, but my experience here wasn't great at all.

First of all, this place is IN THE CUTS. Walking by on this street, which is rarely, I would've never seen this place without any knowledge beforehand that it existed. The store is really small and offers about 3-4 tables to dine at, each with 4 chairs. The set-up seemed a lot similar to a taqueria; with the glass 1/2 window separating customers from the selections of food and the stoves. 

Before even planning a day to come, I researched Kusina's menu and what foods I wanted to eat. I chose a Tuesday because they would have beef steak and pancit. No sisig whatsoever! :[ So i came on a Tuesday around 1:30-2 with a friend to get my craving satisfied. We walked in and perused the selection of foods that were left. No more beef steak. So sad! :[ It was my main reason for going on a Tuesday but the man did say they'd have it again the next day. Only problem was that I wouldn't be coming back. So we ordered ONE order of pancit to share, took the rest of the pork skewers (5), a small order of rice and 2 sodas. It also came with a cup of soup for each of us. Total? 22$. Woow. That blew me away.  But i guess oh wells. I wanted to try it out and now i know.

The pork skewers were really delicious, yes, but they were very small! Not worth it for what we paid for them. Our pancit was okay, it was so not what I had expected or wanted. It was not the same as the one i had when i first tried it. The first pancit i ever tried had a lemon-y/lime-y flavor to it... The one at Kusina was like just plain white noodles with some vegies and pieces of meat. The soup was alright and tasted a little like hamburgers. Hah, that's probably why I thought it was alright. It looked like miso soup without the tofu and seaweed.

Honestly, I  would not be coming back unless someone convinces me and does a really good job at it. The quality of the food and dining experience in comparison to the price i paid was so not worth it. If you want to come and experience it for yourself, by all means. Don't let my review stop you from trying it out, this is just my personal experience and opinion of it.
author: Michael N.

description:
I love these lunch dates with my aunt. 

She's been commuting to SF for as long as I can remember and works downtown.  Imagine my delight when she sent me an email and asked me if I wanted to have lunch with her.

She was so excited to show me this "hole in the wall" Filipino restaurant right across the Hilton (on Mason and Taylor st).  Leave it to my aunt to find a place that won't burn a hole in my pocket either.

Walking in, I felt like I was going into somebody's home.  I was warmly greeted with smiles from the staff behind the counter, even the cook deep-frying the Tilapia turned his head to smile.   The TV is tuned into the ubiquitous (amongst Filipinos anyway) TFC which stands for The Filipino Channel.   There are a couple of tables and stools for those who want to eat in. 

The entrees on the steamer trays look so enticing:  chicken adobo, ginisang upo, lumpia, Dinuguan, etc.  

We were all smiles as we put in our order:  Dinuguan (the famous chocolate meat you keep hearing about, ain't really chocolate!) , Paksiw na Bangus and rice.  For dessert, we each had the $1 Banana Que.  (banana rolled in brown sugar and fried)

Dinuguan is a stew usually cooked with pig's entrails simmered in pork's blood, garlic, chili and vinegar.  But here at Kusina ni Tess, it's made with pork's meat.  A little bit on the fatty side and it could be more spicier. 

The Paksiw na Bangus is made with milkfish, garlic, lots of ginger, bittermelon, and thin slices of eggplant.  I don't recall this dish being traditionally made with bittermelon or eggplant, but I guess, it's a good way to get your veggie for the day. 

The food here is definitely worth a try, and most of the entrees come with rice.  (the lady told us we can have extra rice if we need it) Our meal came to a total of $17 and the servings were enough for two people.  

You can't beat that price for decent Filipino food.
author: Janice C.

description: When you're craving home cookin', and I mean REALLY crave it, you would go to the ends of the Earth to get what you need. But I was definitely happier to find that I could just go the city to get it. Filipino food is non-existent in Sonoma County, so if you're in the mood the easiest (and best) trek is to get here at Kusina Ni Tess. It's a hole-in-the-wall, mom and pop joint and you feel right at home as you walk in. Tito (as I want to call him) will just ask what you want and have you take a seat to immediately enjoy the heavenly food. We ordered the dinuguan and kaldereta with a side of broth and rice (of course!). We just couldn't get enough! I ended up getting food and snacks to go to curb my craving for the next week. I can't wait to come back!
author: Gaile G.

description:
This is a tiny, divey spot with a some very good food with big flavor.

Almost all the food here are prepared and so you can look at all the available items and choose what you'd like to have (Turo-Turo).   I had the Pritong Isda (fried fish - Tilapia) and Laing (taro leaves cooked in a thick and savory coconut milk stew) - everything was great.  The fish did need a bit of saltiness so adding some Patis (fish sauce) made it perfect - it had a nice delicate flavor.  The Laing was fantastic - a favorite dish of mine that I rarely have - it had so much flavor and I can tell that some excellent spices were added to make it taste amazing.  While I wouldn't say it was cheap, it was definitely affordable ($9 for two items and rice).

The place is very small with only 4 tables (1 table for two and 3 tables for four) so I'd suggest not going during peak lunch time hours unless you are planning to take your meal elsewhere...you can also be very friendly and sit next to a stranger if need be.
author: Ken G.

description: The fact that there's a Filipino restaurant a few blocks from the office makes me happy. I tried the sinigang na baboy and it was delicious, almost as good as my lola would make. The (lunch) price is very affordable, $6. It's no frills establishment and the menu selection is decent.  I look forward to repeat visits!
author: John M.

description:
I (James) think the reason why Filipino restaurants have not proliferated like Chinese, Thai or other Asian restaurants is that we Filipinos are very picky when it comes to our native cuisine.  If it doesn't taste as Mom cooked it, then it's not the same.

Kusina Ni Tess is as close as it gets to Mom's Filipino home cooking.  Yesterday, I tried the Pancit Bihon & Pork Adobo. Both dishes were delicious.  I definitely will be coming back when I yearn for Filipino food but can't visit Mom.  The owner/cook, Manny, is very friendly and will allow you to sample before you order.

For what this hole in the wall lacks in decor, it's made up by the flavors of the food and the hospitality of the owner.  You definitely get value for your money.  And for those who say a meal is not meal unless you have white steamed rice, I got a big plate of rice when I ordered the adobo.
author: James R.

description: Good Filipino Food...two scoops of rice and you can choose any 2 items you want for under 9 bucks...looks like they made some changes the place is bigger to accomodate more people...i wouldn't mind coming back to eat at this place again...
author: Carlo R.

description: Great inexpensive Filipino food. Its conveniently located in Union Square rught on Ellis Street. If you love Filipino food and love saving money even more this place is for you. We are staying a block away at parc 55 so it was just around the corner so it was perfect.
author: Nadieshda L.

description: Kusina Ni Tess is the best Filipino restaurant in the Bay Area. The food took me to a trip down the memory lane. The girl behind the counter was genuine, also cracked up a few jokes. If you want to know how food taste like in the Philippines this is exactly the place to go. And don't get me started about the price $. Inexpensive, delicious, and authentic. I'll definitely come back to this place.
author: Mabs A.

description: I was born in the Philippines and now reside in NYC. Went on vacation in SF and found this place right in the middle of downtown next to our hotel. I wish I could go back just for this. Amazing, traditional Filipino food and it's cheap, cheap, cheap!
author: Kevin O.

description: So good! Best Filipino food I've had outside of my best friend's house where her mom made it for us!  I'll be back!!
author: Candice B.

description: Over price! Ok sana kung masarap at may quality ung food kaso hindi eh... Too much oily pa! Not recommended better eat at south city filipino restaurants! Better and delicious!!!
author: Ryan F.

description:
The food was tasty, nice and slow-cooked. We had the adobo (good), the pork stew (our favourite!), the ginger/chicken soup (a little salty but good), the corned beef (fine, did not stand out) and the mango/coconut dessert (good).

The person at the counter was really nice -- when we told her it was our first time here, she actually gave us little plastic spoons to try some of the dishes. 

Prices for the above + 2 sodas (4-5 dishes) was $29, which is a little more than you may expect for a hole-in-the-wall, but would come here again for a fix!
author: Yan K.

description: The beef stew over rice was just amazing. The sauce was so rich and flavorful. Lumpias were really good 'n' crunchy too. Neat little Tenderloin hole-in-the-wall. No krazies outside the premises. I like the owners, as they smile easily. Sarap indeed!
author: Derek N.

description:
This is the place to go when you need a Filipino food fix when in the downtown area. They have nice cooks and great service and the food is really good! It helps that it's the only Filipino restaurant nearby. Prices are good too and they are more than willing to accommodate special requests (i.e. some bulalo soup extra or adobo deep fried). 

The only down side, hence only 4 stars instead of 5, is that it's located on the Tenderloin area.
author: Jonathan S.

description: Portions are extremely generous and everything we had was super tasty. Just like my grandfather's beloved home cooking. We sampled corned beef, picadillo, bangus (milkfish), crispy Pata (amazing!!!), chorizo, lumpia, blood stew and garlic fried rice. Every time I visit a city, I look for Filipino food and this was hands down the best so far!  Sweet and friendly staff. Don't let the neighborhood or small size fool you!
author: Cee A.

description: Been there several times and the food is delicious. Difficult parking, but loading zones expire at 1pm weekdays, so plenty of street parking after 1pm. Friendly service and recently remodeled with more tables and chairs. We tend to get several dishes and take the leftovers home.
author: Leon L.

description: I've eaten here twice and was great each time.  It is the most tender pork skewers ever.  They cook small batches of food right in the front so you know its fresh when you order it.  I have also eaten chicken and pork adobo, both saucy and peppery vinegary.  The complimentary broth they give you to start is a little bland and strange but Filipino friends say it tastes just right.  Good choice of veggies each time, I've had the bitter melon and the winter melon.  Prices are great and I covet one of those banana egg rolls but have yet to indulge.
author: Maya H.

description: I live in the Chicago suburbs and there's not a lot of Filipino restaurants. This place it's authentic Filipino food turo turo style. I ordered the caldereta, chicken adobo, lumpia and tocino. Everything was just perfect.
author: Patrick T.

description: Been back several times since my first review and it keeps getting better. Great food, great service and despite the awful neighborhood, a really pleasant environment.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Let's face it, Filipino food is not for the diet and/or health conscious. After eating it I'm usually left craving salad - and I don't even like salad! That being said, I will excuse the predominance of salt and oil in many of the dishes because the food is so tasty. High cholesterol and hypertension? Bring it on!
 
I took my mom here for lunch while she was visiting. After a weekend of dining at restaurants such as Wayfare Tavern, Bobo's, Izakaya Sozai, Canteen, and Laurel Court (in the Fairmont hotel), I gotta say that this was one of the better (and definitely cheapest!) meals we had.
 
The food itself is worthy of 4 stars, but what brings this unassuming hole-in-the-wall to 5-star status is the incredible service. They were all SOOO nice! Though I'm familiar with a few Filipino dishes by no means am I an expert. In fact, most of their stews and other offerings were foreign to me. Not only was the lady behind the counter extremely patient in describing all the dishes to me, she let me sample most of them! I must've tried at least 5 things before ordering.

We ended up getting rice with 4 items (dinuguan, chicken adobo, bbq chicken kebab, pork picadillo) and beef broth soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=_UQu0_EkMapVmWaKyhokIA). The portions were generous and we took home plenty of leftovers. All the dishes were incredibly flavourful! My favourite was the well-marinated and very tender BBQ CHICKEN (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=K6hvMnOPgLoOxCHeDRkSYQ). Another great dish was the CHICKEN ADOBO (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=V5i46q0uLZkzPKkl8sI13g), which was vinegary with lots of tender chicken. The DINUGUAN, a pork blood stew (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=qyvbG-mXwjzfVgtzbWGPhQ), had a ton of pork - in fact, it was ALL pork. I actually would've liked to see some snout, ears, and intestines. Flavour-wise it was tasty and vinegary but not the best I've had. The PICADILLO (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=IpXhx2tf21QPFRQbmVOPGw) was an aromatic stew with ground pork, potatoes, onions, peas, and carrots. 

As you can see, all we ordered was meat. (Vegetables don't exactly come to mind when I think of Filipino food...) While we were eating, the chef prepared a fresh batch of vegetables and offered us some on the house! Free food? SCORE! We got about half a serving of tasty eggplant, pumpkin, green beans, and bitter melon sautéed with shrimp paste (I think, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=ZgebMZj4ih7ppohwK9mp6Q). Like everything else, this was so flavourful, but definitely not as heavy.

At the end of our meal I realized I forgot to get some LUMPIAS. Being as stuffed as we already were, I didn't want to get a whole order (of 6) so I got a half order for $1.50 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=3UJ0ZkOLaachSKOqamv5xA). These were made to order so they're guaranteed to be hot and crispy.

They must have seen my mom and me eyeing the BIBINGKA sitting on the counter, because they offered us a free sample of that as well! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=USTl04_CDuaRz2rgGG0cRQ) It's a rice flour cake with sliced salted eggs wrapped in banana leaf, which imparted a nice aroma to the cake.

I will definitely be back the next time I'm craving Filipino food, especially since I don't have to go all the way to Daly City! Their menu rotates on a daily basis and some things are only available on certain days, so check before you go! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s6x7VDb6qZ__HV1TjnWzKQ?select=uRD3L1Hj55rM31R9egyioA)
author: Steph L.

description: Legit food. It was a nice break from BK, McD and diner fare.  The lumpia was great. Wish we got there in time for some lechon kawali.  Our fault :(
author: Teresa M.

description:
A hole in the wall and best to get it to-go or bring it to eat elsewhere as they only have 4-5 tables. 

I've never had "real" filipino food as I would think Jollibee doesn't count. I don't recall the name of any dish but everything was delicious. Seems like a family owned place and they welcome you to sample any dish before comitting to it. 

They have those skinny fried pork lumpia but you'll have to order it.
author: Maggie C.

description: is in my neigborehood, i love filipino food and i just found the right place, i have enjoy so far the stuffed fish, lumpias, adobo, cornbeef , embutido, and my favorit babingka. If you want enjoy filipino food here in downtown visit Kusina ni tess, the people that work is very friendly and of course you will enjoy the food. I saw a review that mention they dont take credit card but they do, minimum charge for it is $10.
author: Manfredo R.

description: This was my first Filipino restaurant.  I enjoyed it and will go back.  The staff was very friendly food was tasty and well prepared.  Quiet littlee stop.
author: Ben C.

description:
I've never had a chance to eat Filipino food, so this is first time.

The place is kinda dinky, but that never really puts me off.  I asked the guy behind the counter for a recommendation and I was a little worried he would recommend me something super expensive (I worry about that EVERYWHERE, so I'm not trying to be racist or something), but he let me try this beef steak thing (I think that's what he said it was).  I thought it tasted great, asked him the price and was surprised it would only be $5.50.  Got that, along with an order of lumpia for $9.22.  Not too bad.

Sat down with the beef and rice first as I waited for the lumpia.  The sauce was pretty good, if a little oily.  The beef tasted great, but some of the pieces had large chunks of fat on them.  I just left those parts off, and enjoyed the rest.  So so good.  I devoured almost half my plate before my lumpia came in.  They weren't fresh (saw them take them out of a freezer), but they were still yummy.  Probably one of the best $10 I ever spent.....

Don't let the neighborhood or the setting put you off.  It's really good, and it's GREAT bang for the buck.  I'll definitely come here more often to try the other menu items that were unknown to me :).
author: Filmer Y.

description: I love this spot. Little tuck a way spot with great phillipine cuisine. I love the breakfeast there. Very reasonably priced as well. Can't wait to go back.
author: John G.

description:
I'll make this quick and delicious. Just like their Crispy Pata. 

My BF is a HUGE cripsy pata fan, and when he found this place, he nearly died and went to heaven. Right near his work! 

The portion was plentiful, hot and juicy and only $12! Can't beat that. It was so much food he had to share it with his co-workers.. Great deal!
author: Chi N.

description: Yelp says this place opens on Saturdays.  Their store front says they are open as well with hours posted.  Well... wut happen this pass weekend?  Still haven't been.
author: Demanding T.

description: Great Filipino Food for Lunch Time
author: Jonathan M.

description:
FOOD:  Authentic?  Yes.  As in, I could've sworn my own Lola was the one stirring up that coconuty-goodness of Laing (taro leaves with coconut milk, and little baby shrimp.)  The pusit (squid), also prepped the way I ate it as a young girl.  The adobo was decent, a little oily for my taste.  But it's too tall an order to top my Mom's, where the chicken gets so tender it falls off the bone, then you toss it on a pan to get a nice mix of tender and crispy.  (Though, Dad, you've somehow tweaked your timpla of adobo and cooking style, that the difference is nearly imperceptible.)  Turon (saba banana with jackfruit wrapped in lumpia wrapper) was pretty good, glad they didn't skimp on the langka, though I prefer less sugar when they fry it up.

SERVICE:  There's a counter up front where you order, then you seat yourself at the line of small tables along the side.  Aaaalmost like a stand at Market-Market, just in the Tenderloin.  The people are friendly, and there's a mix of people eating there.

PRICE:  Great!

Salamat Tita Tess, and I'll be back!
author: Hanneke F.

description: Was there when we ran the SF marathon. Food was great and allowed me to have good old home cooking. Place is small but certainly a bargain. Staff is friendly and courteous. If I ever go back to SF, this is one of those places I certainly left my heart for pinoy cooking.
author: Michael A.

description:
Im not very experienced with Filipino food, in fact, I generally eat about anything. Literally. So most of my reviews are based upon the people who work there, the people who dine there and if I dig the place.

I give this place 5 stars because the guy (owner?) behind the counter (Manny) rocked out and so did everyone else. He gave me a taste test of nearly every food he had. 

Then while waiting, I taught the Spanish speaking guy who works for him how to say in English "I love you and not a day goes by that I don't think of you", it was for his gf in Central America, he wanted to impress her with his English.

The food was great by the way, I ate 2/5 and had to take a food induced nap.
author: Fabian O.

description:
They had me at Chicken Tocino =)

Something is comforting about garlic fried rice in the a.m.. But since I work in the FiDi, the closest I had to my b-fast of champions was JolliBee's (I was desperate).

UNTIL Kusina Ni Tess!!! 

They serve HUGE portions of yummy food for CHEAP!  I mean my $5 chicken tocino order feeds for 2!

Unfortunately they only serve b-fast from 7:30-9:30, but around 9ish they start to run out of bfast stuff.  But have no fear, call them in the early a.m. and they will put your order on the side. So when I come rolling in there late, its waiting for me =)

I've had lunch here, and I was just lost.  Other then sising and b-fast I don't know much about authentic Filipino food.  But the sweet nice ppl there helped me make my choices very wisely.  They didn't mind my gazillion and one questions. and offered me samples and free soup!  

Filipino food tend to run on the more greasy side... so the fav thing I had for lunch that time was the Pork Kebab and this eggplant omelet. 

My all time favorite is still the b-fast... so get your garlic breathe on at 8am in the morning here!
author: Deanna T.

description: Eggplant dish is absolutely terrible. The taste is inexplicably sour and there is some unknown substance that might be egg in it. Staff refused to explain what it was and just shouted "no meat." Items on the menu were not available.
author: Jenn B.

description:
My tummy was so bloated from the meal that I hit food coma immediately after we left. Though my afternoon passed by sluggishly, I was thoroughly satisfied by the food!

I really can't describe the dishes we ordered, much less pronounce it, but try the adobo and the fish! There are plenty of meaty dishes that are all good (The two of us ordered 5-6 dishes and actually ate them all...hence, the food coma). 

:) Definitely coming back for kare-kare (supposedly fridays!!)
author: Tory L.

description: Excellent food.  About as close to homemade Filipino food as you can get.  My mom, who is from the Philippines, gives it her seal of approval.  Try the bibingka!
author: Kathleen D.

description: Turon! I always buy at least 4 or 5 to bring some home for my mom. One time they didn't have any left, but the lady was nice enough to make a new batch for me when i promised to buy 6 of them!
author: Le T.

description:
Four stars for:

1. Convenience- located in the heart of Downtown San Francisco.
2. Flavor and quality- not the best Filipino food, but I'd give it a star.
3. Price- very affordable, the owner would also fry your adobo for free if you ask him nicely!
4. Selection- wow, on any given day they would have 4-5 dishes like adobo, sinigang, fried fish, asado, menudo, laing etc. available.

One star negated:

1. Cleanliness!!!!!
author: mikhael b.

description:
My manager took me out to lunch for my birthday, and the place we originally wanted to go to had already closed their lunch service (it was 2PM), so we walked around and decided to come in here. 

First of all, let me say that this place isn't very clean and only has 4-5 small tables to sit at, but I'm assuming people get their food to go anyway. It reminds me of small family-run restaurants in Hong Kong, where most customers are regulars and don't mind how run-down it is. They had a television on a Filipino channel, so we got to enjoy some kind of Asian telenovela while we ate. The staff was friendly and did their own thing while we poked and peeked around. 

I think we had just missed the lunch rush here, so they didn't have any noodles left. White rice it is! Carbs on carbs. We decided to do this family-style, and shared:
Pork Adobo: I've only ever had chicken adobo before, and this was a lot less vinegary and more gravy-y than what I remember. The meat was really tender and flavourful, and there wasn't too much fat attached. It was, however, kind of oily but it wasn't too bad.
Laing: Probably my favourite part of my meal. This is taro leaves cooked in coconut milk. It tastes like sweet curry, and it melts in your mouth. Because it's veggies, it feels healthy and it's amazing with rice. CARBS ON CARBS.
BBQ Pork Skewers: Well, I really like barbeque and skewers, so no complaints here. I would've preferred chicken or beef, because I've never really understood what pork tastes like... 
Tinapa: The meat on their fried fish was a little on the dry side, and was hard to eat without really getting our hands dirty (damn flimsy plastic forks), but I really liked how they seasoned/marinated it. Not too salty and the skin was very crispy.
Beef Stew: This was really bland, and I had maybe 30% of mine. I think they were trying to get rid of it, because there were no veggies and no beef, just broth and oil. Nope.

We each got a huge plate of rice, and the portions were huge for one person. Everything came to $23, which is really cheap for how much food we got! I think this was my first time having an authentic Filipino meal, and I will definitely come by again to try more items.
author: Katie M.

description:
The best Filipino food I've ever had to pay for! The selection, which rotates from day to day, is quite diverse and can accommodate a vegetarian satisfactorily, of which I am not. Otherwise, and this is true generally of Filipino cuisine, the meat dishes are the focal points. For sheer variety this place would make me think twice about going home for a Filipino meal. The chicken adobo was flavorful without being overly salty or vinegary, and now that I've discovered that you can request it to be fried, I'll have to try that common variation as well! The laing we ordered didn't contain any shrimp or meat, just the taro leaves and coconut milk, and was delicious just the same, a very comforting food. The dinuguan was, hands down, my favorite part of my meal, and it surprised my companions with its quality, especially after they'd gotten a sample and brief explanation of what it is (pork butt in pork blood). Our meals came with rice and some "soup" which was actually just sinigang broth without the bok choy and beef. 

The location is pretty small and its exterior hardly stands out (despite the bright yellow awning), a real hole-in-the-wall place, but none of this should matter given the delicious and authentic food. And the gentleman (who reigns from Bulacan!) who is frequently at the door is genuinely invested in providing a filling meal. My companions are relatively new to Filipino food and loved all of it. In fact, we bartered over who was going to be taking what after we'd stuffed our faces. 

I've been searching for quality Filipino spots in the city since moving here, and though this is actually my first stop, it'll probably be the primary one. I've yet to try the rellenong bangus or kare-kare, but will be trying them out soon.
author: Jake m.

description:
OMG, I am so happy that I found out that there is this lovely Filipino restaurant down the street.  Garlic Fried rice served as breakfast till 9:30AM, sometimes there are leftovers, under $5. 
The chef is so friendly and offered me free soup. 
Kare Kare, bitter Lemon etc.

Will be back for the Bibinka
author: Tigre T.

description:
The taro leaves cooked in coconut milk is the best. They taste kind of like spinach, but sweetened from the coconut. The owner (?) guy who always works there is really friendly and nice. Maybe a little 'overly' friendly. But I guess that's not necessarily a bad thing.

I always see Filipino people here, so it's pretty authentic. Although the price is a tad on the authentic side for what it is. Maybe because it's near downtown?

I also ordered the Halo halo, it was kind of interesting. Definitely mix it, I kind of made that mistake of not mixing it...newb me, but Halo halo means Mix Mix It's basically sweet beans, crushed ice, and coconut milk (maybe some other stuff too).
author: Xavier G.

description:
It's a hole in the wall with very little seating, but the food is definitely legit! It definitely has a very mom and pop feel to it as the owners are running the place and they seem to have regulars who they know on a personal level. We got here pretty early for lunch, and lingered a little bit longer while the ladies behind the counter fried up some turons.

This review is based on the food more than anything. I personally did not grow up on Filipino food but my husband says that the food here is as authentic as they come. The actual establishment is a little lacking and could definitely use an upgrade but it did not detract from the experience. I can imagine that the place can get extremely packed during breakfast or lunch hours. It does look like they do a lot more takeaway and catering orders though.

This place gives you all the rice you can eat, which is great because most of the food they offer pair with rice very well. The sinigang here is delicious, and actually better than what I remember trying in the Philippines. It is sour (as it should be) but it definitely is backed with a lot of flavor from the pork and vegetables in the soup. We also had the Filipino Beef Steak and that was good. I wasn't a big fan of it as it tasted a little sour but my husband loved it. It supposedly tasted like how it traditionally is prepared. The last item we had was giniling which is pork cooked with vegetables and left to steep in its juices. This was really tasty. And it definitely went really well on top of rice. It is a tad greasy but it definitely is quite good. We also had the halo-halo after the meal and it was a little difficult to stir as it was served in a plastic cup. Regardless, it was just okay and I've definitely had better from my local Filipino restaurants.

Overall, I really enjoyed the food. I will definitely be back next time I am in San Francisco!
author: Grace P.

description:
Just had their loganisa, egg, and sinanag (garlic rice) for breakfast.  It was yummy and their loganisa wasn't too oily which is great!  All-in-all, for a breakfast this yummy at $4.50 it's a great bargain!  And, it was a great way to start off a Friday morning!  

Of course, b/c of the garlic greatness I have to hunt down my toothpaste and toothbrush and brush my teeth before my meetings. :)
author: Raymond G.

description:
Yum.

My first hint that this would probably be good was the 10-deep line to get in at lunch time.

My second was that everybody eating at Tess' was Filipino.

Yes, it's a small place.  Yes, it's steam table food.  Yes, it can be crowded.  You consider these to be negative?!

I waited about 10 minutes to order my food.  While I was waiting, I watched them prep fresh dishes and move them to the steam table.  That's a Good Sign(tm).

I grabbed some pork afritada, pancit and dinuguan.  All three were pretty yummy... and the portions were huge.  I washed my meal down with two sodas and still spent less than $12... including the complimentary white rice.

If you're looking for individual seating here -- give up.  There are three tables set for four-tops.

You will, however, stand a good chance of grabbing a seat at the communal table in the back.  And you should.  Best seating in the house.

At the back table, seated with around eight people I'd never met before, I had a really nice lunch and a lot of warm, friendly and fun conversation.

The food here is very good... but the folks that work here and eat here make the place.

Going back to try the bangus :)
author: Mark B.

description: The lumpia was delicious, and the pork was great. The rice was clumpy. The atmosphere was kind of homely (take that as you will). Oh yeah, banana ketchup!
author: Eric L.

description: I don't care much for carbs, especially white rice.  BUT I've been craving KNT's garlic fried rice all day -- outrageously delicious and will protect anyone from vampires.  I stopped by one morning to get Pilipino breakfast - $4!  And I think it took me three days to get through it (GFR reheats very well.)  Must come back here for the kara-kare and of course, a super-sized portion of lumpia.   Saraap!
author: Amelyn C.

description: The guy that works here was so super nice and friendly that my traveling companion, who is a meat and potatoes kind of guy, agreed to eat here after getting to taste some of the food.  The food was amazingly tasty and VERY well priced.  Highly recommended.
author: Pat B.

description:
Tess's restaurant reminded me of a district called Quiapo in Manila where thousands pay homage to the famous Spanish colonial cathedral. 
Philippine culture- from high society to panhandlers pass through here to buy fresh sampaguita (jasmine lei) maybe even jackfruit while waiting in horse drawn carriages as they meander through the streets, serenaded by a cacophony of honking horns to ease the bottleneck traffic along. 
Sidewalk restaurants flourish here as well along with dozens of street vendors, ,fruits stands, souvenir shops and herbal stores (and the list goes on) . I can easily see Tess's kitchen here-- a little quiapo style restaurant serving authentic PiliPino food and that's Pinoy with a CAPITAL P! 
The menu changes on a daily basis offering the following: 

SINIGANG- Sour soup in tomato/tamarind base fish or pork, 
KARE-KARE- Peanut stew with oxtail with string beans, eggplant,cabbage 
NILAGA- ginger beef broth with beef shank with potatoes and bok-choy 
CRISPY PATA- deep fried ham hocs with vinegar dipping sauce 
LUGAW- Pilipino congee with saffron, ginger and chicken, 
LECHONG KAWALI- crispy roast pork with side sauce, 
TINAPA- Fried marinated fish (in coconut vinegar, loads of garlic and whole peppercorns) and of course the ubiquitous 
ADOBO- chicken or pork- braised meat in vinegar, soysauce, garlic and bay leaf. 
DESSERTS: like palitao (flat rice cake dumplings with coconut shavings), puto (steamed rice cake) and halo halo (just get it) 
The restaurant also serves breakfast with staples like tocino (marinated savory ham), tinapa and longanisa (sausage) 

PS- The owners and cooks were always eager to chat up a conversation and introduce you to PINOY cuisine given the generous helpings on the plate! 3.5 STARS place.!
author: Arissa C.

description: My friend and I were looking for something different for lunch. Luckily it showed up on Yelp. For $6 you get filled with rice, a topping of your choice and their soup. The owner was so helpful. He allowed us to try different things until we could make a choice. I ended up with the adobo chicken. My friend got the pork stew thing which also had potatoes and vegetables. I would go for the beef stew next time and their fish. I would try getting it to go since the place is tiny and it can get packed quickly.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I finally stopped by Kunisa Ni Tess and I was really impressed by the authentic Filipino cuisine, the friendly staff let me sample a few items before ordering and I ordered the taro leaves in coconut sauce, the adobo chicken, plate of rice and also a free bowl of soup that was included with the meal, I thought the food was excellent! they have a pretty good variety to choose from, the restaurant is very small only had around 4 - 5 small tables.

the prices are very reasonable, if you want some really good Filipino home style cooking, this is the place to go! I should come here more often, Im glad I found this nice little hole in the wall.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
Kusina Ni Tess is a hole-in-the-wall eatery serving home cooking Filipino food.  Home cooking usually means the food is yummy, just like how your mom cooks it. Unfortunately, the  over oily chicken adobo, bland noodles, and lumpias that I ate were not very good. They tasted exactly like the dishes my mom made--not tasty. 

Worse, the portions were very small and the prices were quite high. I am not a big eater. But I were still hungry after I ate two small pieces of chicken (~$3.5), noodles (~$3.5), and six lumpias ($3) and had to eat a burger at Carl's Jr. 

Skip it!
author: Ed W.

description:
I am so sorry.  I am really sorry.  I don't want to do my Filipino peeps any harm.  I will eat in the dingy-est dive in town (even to Pakwan with their basmati-cockrochi rice) but man, it's just not cool when the restaurant fries fish two inches away from you. 

I was at Kusina ni Tess with some non-Filipino co-workers (it was their idea, not mine) this afternoon and Tess decides to fry up a boat load of milkfish (bangus). My co-workers didn't complain (I guess they didn't want to offend) but we seriously left the place smelling like Pacific Super.   

The food was below average - everything was greasy, greasy, greasy(the forks and spoons were still a little greasy from the last patron).  The Chicken adobo - greasy (actually, they should rename this dish to chicken swimming in grease and a little bit of soy sauce). The pork Chop - greasy. The Sinigang -super greasy (little chunks of fat swimming around in your soup). Agh! Why can't Filipinos here cook without so much grease? 

Judging by the lunchtime crowd, it is obvious that the Hilton Hotel workers keep this restaurant alive.  If I were Filipino and worked at the Hilton, I would demand for a little bit more quality from Tess.
I know that most of them don't really have a choice (there really is no other Filipino place around) - but please Hilton workers, next time you are at Tess', tell her to cut the grease a little.
author: Clarice V.

description: I am very new in SF and I've been eating non-filipino since a week or so. There are many foods here we dont have back home (Zurich, Switzerland), this week I had from burgers in Cheesecake Factory to Froyos, good dumplings and shumai in china town, corndogs, delicious crabs in fishermans wharf etc. but as a filipino, I was craving for some white rice with "Ulam" and so, someone recommended me Kusina Ni Tess which is 2 blocks from my hotel (thank god) and I ran quickly to this place. I had fried embutido and gabi and it was delicious as expected! i kept it simple, big meals like kare-kare or palabok I'll order next time. honestly, I wouldn't know what to decide, because there is alot of choices.
author: -ed- G.

description:
It's a cramped place nearby a porn store .. seriously. But it's the Tenderloin. 
Anyway, I hate to be so harsh here, but I feel like I've experienced better tasting food & better service at other places (i.e. Irma's in the Mission). This place doesn't seem to have the food I want when I need it.
author: Annie D.

description: Good prices for food I always have leftovers. The Owner is very friendly and always gives me samples when I come in. I like this place since it is close to where I reside and I have leftovers that last a day or so:D I am not big on Banana but the dessert banana sugar coated egg roll looking thing is amazing as are the veggie rolls. :D
author: Shelley M.

description:
I went there for lunch today and I was floored by Manny having set aside a stew called KarKari based on our brief conversation this past Monday.  I also had this with a vegetable dish called Laing.  Laing reminded me of a Thai dish without the spiciness.  It was delicious but it did not compare to the KariKari  The stew dish was very tasty.  It was rich and flavorul.  I felt like I was eating at somebody's home back in the Philippines.

I was so full that I had to take a fried banana dessert to go that I promised my sister to taste.  I know she will be very jealous when she reads this review! :-)

Best to Manny and the restaurant!
author: Joe C.

description: I was craving some Filipino food so I happen to come across this place here on Yelp. I decided to take a chance and try it out. My husband went to pick up the food and it is basically a little hole in the wall. For 4 items he paid around $21. Not bad. Food was oily but what do you expect. Food was tasty though. We do plan on going back and try more dishes.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
SERIOUS POOR PEOPLE FOOD. 

2/11
the food here has gotten a lot better in the past few months.  the kare kare is really good.  they actually use oxtail.  they at one time used pork chunks. (what's up with that).  Everything is pretty good and rice is included with no charge. 

2010
Been craving Filiipino food.    I thought I'd come back and give this Tess another try.    So, much better, but still a bit greasy.   Kare Kare is pretty good,  not generic when this place first opened.   Diniguan sp? is really good.   Everything is much better.   Service is still a bit slow, but oh well.   Now come at least once a week.    

the service is a bit slow, but call in your order if you can get through.  I actually waited over an hour to talk to someone.  you still have to wait when you get there.  They're very unorganized.   The last day i went there,  there were five people behind the counter.  Three people in line and I waited 15 minutes to get my food.  I over heard someone sitting at one of the tables that she waited over a half an hour to be served. So heads up with the wait.  

my rating went from 4 stars to 2.

5/10  really wanted filipino food.   went there after work and ordered menudo.   MENUDO????  that was NO menudo. it had hotdogs.  i think this is poor people filipino food from the projects.  The kare-kare the serve is now pork chucks.  

my new rating went from a 2 to a 1. (somebody shut this place down).
author: jeff a.

description: I went to this place expecting a decent & authentic Filipino lunch at a "decent" price based on the reviews I read here. Damn was I led astray! The food was great & they had the whole Pinoy turo-turo experience down when we paid for our food, the lady behind the counter blatantly inflated our bill while shamelessly speaking Tagalog like I wouldn't understand it. 4 entrees & 2 orders of rice cost $38 freaking dollars?? The bill wasn't even itemized at all which made it difficult to figure out what we were being charged for. This is a disgusting practice I would expect in a ghetto area of Manila, not in San Francisco. Don't go here unless you don't care about being scammed. I won't ever be back. Period!!
author: Tomas R.

description: love it! I was in town for a conference @ the Hilton across the street and stumbled upon this fabulous eatery. The place is a bit run down.. okay hole in the wall, but it has a nice homey feel (like I'm in Southeast Asia!) and it's served cafeteria style. It's nothing fancy, but the prices were decent ($7-9). I had the pork adobo (YUMMMM) with white rice, and when I asked them not to give me too many fatty pieces, they were OK about it! And it's true- they do give huge portions, but I am a glutton, and I devoured all of it. They have other options too, such as fried fish, chicken dishes, stews, and if you don't know, you can point or just ask (they will clarify). The cook/server (stocky guy) was so friendly. I went 2 days in a row and he remembered me! They also make/sell some sweets there.
author: Graciete L.

description: When I can't make it to either my aunt's house or Daly City for my Pinoy food fix, I come here. The service is wonderful - the owners are very nice and offer taste tests of what's being offered that day. The food is pretty good as well - their lumpia and kare kare are delicious. There's not a lot of room here to have a sit down meal so I suggest getting take out and eating at Yerba Buena Gardens or anywhere outside. You can see me walking around downtown, turon in hand.
author: Devy E.

description:
My co-worker and I are doing a pan-Asian lunch tour of San Francisco and today we drew "Philippines" from the box of crinkled up post-it notes bearing the names of 12 Asian countries.

Well, San Francisco, despite swimming in Asian Culture is lacking any real consortium of Filipino cuisine. Note to self.

We found Kusina Ni Tess after some quick Yelping and I would say that most of these reviews are pretty accurate. Very homestyle - Tess was very accomodating and even let me try a few of the dishes before I picked my lunch platter. Noticing my small frame and apprehension to the mongo-load of rice she wanted to dish me, she conceeded to providing a smaller portion. I have never really eaten much Filipino food and found it to be greasy and mysterious, but all around very tasty. I tried the purple string beans with chunks of pork fat paired with a type of creamed spinach in sweet coconut milk. I also had two small bowls of the peppered beef broth which was excellent, but a littly salty. Atmosphere was good, but I had wished it was slightly cleaner. My co-worker had two meat dishes, one chicken curry and the other was an asian style meatloaf. She didn't feel too great afterwards, but I think it was because she ate too much of the fried banana wrapped in lumpia skin for dessert.

All in all, I liked the experience but will probably not return unless they tidy up a bit. The recipes were good and definitely unique. The flavors reminded me of a blend between southern Chinese cuisine and Indian.
author: Nicole S.

description: This place is as good as it gets. The people are VERY friendly and gave us free samples of anything we wanted as it was our first time. The food tasted amazing and there was plenty of it. The corn (like) bread is phenomenal and the Adobo can't be beat. Top 5 cheap eat in the city.
author: Ben T.

description: The nicest, friendliest woman in San Francisco works at Kusina Ni Tess.  I was working late for a conference, and ran out to get some food here before it closed.  I had tried on two prior occasions (one a year ago) to try the food here, and this was my first successful time.  The only Filipino food I was familiar with was adobo and lumpia, so I ordered pork adobo and lumpia.  I asked her what else was good and she started giving me tastes.  Of everything. (there was no one else in the restaurant at the time).  So I can say that: the taro root in coconut milk is something you gotta try; the orange noodles cooked in cream of mushroom soup, mashed tofu and egg are delish; the chicken something and vegetables are good, the lumpia is so good, the stuff with shrimp paste is yummy.  They have BBQ pork on a stick.  Let me be clear:  BBQ. Pork. On a stick. And, she answered every single question (and I asked a lot) about what stuff was.  So:  very good, inexpensive food and service with more than a smile - Kusina Ni Tess is a winner.  Did I mention the BBQ pork on a stick?
author: Cookie C.

description: This place is a total hole in a wall establishment with a porn store just doors away. So it ain't got ambiance , who cares. When you need some Lumpia and some  cheap homey food and you're downtown , it's the place to be. Huge portions on steamy fluffy rice.
author: Sophia C.

description: I've always passed this place and never had a chance to stop in. How glad I am that I did today. I was feeling a good filipino meal and yelped near Union Square as I was getting into work. All I read were positive and thorough reviews! So, I thought they couldn't fail me! The moment I walked in a welcome greeting came from a friendly man named Manny who asked if this was my first time to visit Kusina Ni Tess. My reply was yes. He then welcome's me and starts off by sending samples my way! I got to try the food before I bought! So I went with the most talked about Laing: Taro leaves marinated in coconut milk. Delicious! As well as the Pork Adobo: A soy sauce and vinegar cooked mixture with pork. Manny then offered to prepare the adobo another way by deep frying the adobo and sampled it for me! He said if you like it prepared this way I will do it for you. But, I preferred the other way. I thought that was extra thoughtful!!! Talk about service. Manny then serves me with the following including a bowl of soup complimentary on the side and free rice refills that I didn't have to go back for with such a generous amount that was served! I had leftovers for my boyfriend to try and he absolutely loved it! Thank you Manny and Tess! I will be back for sure and will bring you business! You all met my delightfullnesss and more!
author: Desirea O.

description: I was introduced to this place by my friends that always -I mean always- go there.  It was pretty busy but the hospitality was soo friendly that they made room for the three of us.  The food was just made so everything was nice and fresh.  It' near the TL so don't be expecting any fansy smanshy environment but I do recommend this 'hole in the wall'!
author: Maria E.

description:
Loganisa breakfast this morning was great and a steal at $4 and they were curious with my request for some fresh garlic for my sucat (vinegar)

The only complaint about this place I have is they don't serve Leche Flan daily.  Their flan is freaking delicious with just the right consistency.  Bibinka is good too but I just wish they had some pineapple in it.

I need to come back and get some mechado, looks and smells great!
author: deryck s.

description:
Tes's Kitchen is definitely a hidden gem on the outskirts of the TL. Having worked in the Union Square area and now downtown, this is the closest you're going to get to authentic Filipino food where you don't have to venture too deep into cracky territory.

Chicken and pork adobo, fried tilapia fish, dinaguan ("chocolate meat"), calderada (beef, ox-tail), chicken tinola (soup), sinigang na baboy (pork) or isda (fish) to name a few of the main dishes. The menu varies from day to day, but they often have 6-8 mains to choose from. Lumpia is sometimes on the menu, and WE ALL LOVE LUMPIA!! Just today they had freshly made turon (fried wrapped banana, glazed with sticky sugar)....Scrumptious!! You can get a huge plate of rice and a main dish for $6 even. Add turon or lumpia for another $1, or a tall cocounut or cantelope juice for $1-1.50, for a total of less than $9! That's a deal.

Although Tes' Kitchen may not have the expansive selection as the more commercial restaurants like Goldilocks (closest one is in the Excelsior District) or your nearby Jolli Bee's (McDonald's of the Philippines), but this place is simple, more local, and in my opinion authentic.

It's a small hole in the wall, so it doesn't fit many. Customers are your usual nearby workers from adjacent hotels or local community members. Don't expect ambiance either, you can get that in a ritzy hotel restaurant by the Square. But they do speak ENGLISH for all you non-fluent Tagalog speakers like me.

Hours?? I don't know, I've only come here for lunch the past few years. Whenever I get that crave, and mom's place is too far for lunch, I come to Auntie Tes'.
author: Barbie D.

description: What a surprise! Across the street from the employee entrance to the Hilton I grabbed A BIG breakfast of Giniling, eggs & a HUGE plate of rice for $4! Though breakfast here is only served from 7-9:30am, they had plenty of breakfast & lunch dishes out. (Lunch/dinner will run you about $4-8.) I almost got the longunisa, eggs & garlic fried rice (my own childhood staple with lots of ketchup..) for only $3.50 but I came a little late. Next time I'll try the desserts or grab some halo halo on the way but.... but today, I was stuffed! They also have a list specials that change daily (kare-kare on Fridays) and they cater about 23 different dishes, perfect for potlucks! I was told they were recently under new management. The employees are helpful & kind.... I will definitely come back.
author: Eugene G.

description: I worked about 4 blocks away and sometimes I feel like having Filipino food, so what a surprise that I discovered this small gem in the area. I've been there 3 times during already. Had the pork adobo twice and the beef stew over steam rice and was quite pleased.The portions are quite big, they even offered  a bowl of soup too. I don't mind fish being fry right there because you know it is freshly cooked.  I'm trying the fried fish next time. The staff is courteous. Reasonable prices, main dishes are either $6 or $7, but  I rather  eat here than having a burger from Burger King or Carl's Jr. My only complaint is that the volume on the TV way too high. Non Philippine reviewer, but enjoy the cuisine.
author: Hum V.

description: This is the real deal!  No pretense (folks have already mentioned the location so I ain't even going there); just good, wholesome, flavorful food served with lots of love.  Just like home.
author: Byron J.

description: Swung by around 11am on a Saturday hoping that there would be some brunch-silog, but it was all lunch.  Considering that I didn't have to jump in my car and shoot down to Daly City/San Bruno, it wasn't too bad.  Definitely one of the better Filipino places in the city.  Had a huge serving of rice with dinuguan (if you don't know what that is...better google it) and some chicken.  That with a can of coconut juice...all for $8.50.  Chicken was good, but the diniguan was a little runny and bland for my taste.
author: Mark D.

description: Tes's is a hole in a wall canteen.  Not a fancy place, just a take out and a small area to sit down.  Food are average nothing special to stand out.  tried their pansit, just average.
author: S S.

description: I've ordered take out twice, and will do so many times again. Everything I've had thus far has been really really good, adobo, lumpia, banana lumpia, taro, you name it.
author: Will B.

description:
San Francisco, despite it's sizable Filipino population, is quite lacking in good Filipino restaurants.  Every so often you'll find a mom and pop operation somewhere, with mixed results.  I'm glad to report that this place does it quite right.

The Pros:
The Food is great!  They specialize in traditional Filipino family food, they have a menu that rotates, with a set of 5-6 entrees to choose from everyday.  The things to look out for: The bulalo is excellent... and it comes with as much rice and sabaw you want, no extra charge (huge plus!).  The dinaguan is excellent as well (and dinaguan is usually done soooo bad).  And a breakfast of chicken tocino, two eggs over easy and garlic fried rice is why this place is getting a full five stars.  It is crazy delicious.
This is the friendliest place I ever been to.   The owner, Manny and his wife run the kitchen and their two young kids are often running around the restaurant somewhere.  Grandma also works in the kitchen.  The have TFC (The Filipino Channel) playing on TV all day.  Manny will make a genuine effort to learn your name the first time you come in, and if you're Filipino, ask you where in the Philippines you're from and generally talk your ear off.  

The Bad:
The food is unapologetically Filipino, and may turn off the random finicky tourist walking in from the Hilton.
Food is not cooked to order, it's mall food court style.  You can't really do Filipino food any other way though, we're a culture that really likes stew-like things and that takes a while to cook.  They do however cook all day in small batches, it's always pretty much been fresh every time I go, even at closing time.
And that leads to the main bad.  The place closes at 5pm and is completely closed on a Sunday.  That kind of makes it tough for us 9-to-5ers to get here BUT you can call in an order and Manny will have it ready for you to pick up till about 5:30pm.
The place is quite small.  It's very clean.  The place kind of smells like fish, but we Filipinos do in general.  Don't laugh.  You know what I mean.

The Gist:
To any Filipino yuppie here in the city, the best way I describe going to this place is like it's a great big hug from you lola, and then she'll feed you and disparage you for being too thin.  And sometimes you just need that.
author: John Paul M.

description: This is a little Filipino hole in the wall restaurant with authentic tasting food, cheap too, no frills.  Reminds me of old karinderya near university belt, a bit of nostalgia. Turo turo style, so all the food is there to be seen and you get to decide based on how it looks.  Rice is plentiful, with clear broth for the asking. Then there's dessert of turon and bibingka-togo as we could no longer eat them on the spot.  Seating is limited, but lucky for us we got there at 1pm.  I would go there again when I go to the city.
author: maria j.
